- gate-project-config-gerrit http://logs.openstack.org/96/498796/3/check/gate-project-config-gerrit/178446f/ : SUCCESS in 1m 43s
- gate-project-config-layout http://logs.openstack.org/96/498796/3/check/gate-project-config-layout/3093592/ : SUCCESS in 7m 43s
- gate-project-config-irc-access http://logs.openstack.org/96/498796/3/check/gate-project-config-irc-access/0c80696/ : SUCCESS in 5m 57s
- gate-project-config-jenkins-project http://logs.openstack.org/96/498796/3/check/gate-project-config-jenkins-project/3531e84/ : SUCCESS in 1m 43s'}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2017-08-29 13:38:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Are we sure we want to do that?

I don't think anyone is going to write Tempest tests for Aodh since we're using Gabbi. What's going to be imported in this repo?"}, {'account_id': 12393, 'date': '2017-08-29 13:54:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> Are we sure we want to do that?
 > 
 > I don't think anyone is going to write Tempest tests for Aodh since
 > we're using Gabbi. 
 
> What's going to be imported in this repo?

We are going to import intree aodh tempest plugin https://github.com/openstack/aodh/tree/master/aodh/tests/tempest to a seperate repo as per queen's goal [https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/queens/split-tempest-plugins.html]. We run aodh tempest tests in CI."}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2017-08-29 14:05:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Those tests barely test anything. They're barely maintained inside the Aodh repository. I can't see how it's a good idea to move them into another repository, whatever the TC decided."}, {'account_id': 5196, 'date': '2017-08-29 14:34:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

@jd_ then delete the plugin from the aodh repo. (although I expect you'll find a bunch of people depend on it for their ci if you try to do that) Keeping the plugin in tree has negative effects outside of just the aodh project. (you can read the goal doc for the background, just the first section) This isn't about blindly following a community goal or trying to change how a project does its testing, but is about trying to make all the tempest plugins out there work together and work in sane manner for the plugin's users."}, {'account_id': 2813, 'date': '2017-08-29 15:27:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

It's less coverage of the tempest code, you must also setup all devstack jobs we currently run.

But I don't like the idea of splitting the repo, it's just more work for our team for no value and a waste of CI resources..."}, {'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2017-08-29 15:34:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

The jobs will be changed as it happened for all split plugins. In the long run is actually less work, because you can handle the tempest plugins as branchless like tempest, so you don't need to backport the fixes for the tests in the older branches.
There are reasons why this is a common community goal for Queens."}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2017-08-29 16:37:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Who's gonna maintain this repo?"}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2017-08-29 16:45:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

for reference, since it came up in some irc conversation related to this patch: there's the start of a plugin for doing random gabbi tests with tempest: https://github.com/cdent/gabbi-tempest

(it's not fully ready yet, but patches welcome. A needed change is to allow where the gabbi files are load to be defined from a caller that uses the plugin)"}, {'account_id': 12393, 'date': '2017-08-29 17:37:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> Who's gonna maintain this repo?
This repo is going to be maintained by the Ceilometer project team."}, {'account_id': 1921, 'date': '2017-09-05 14:56:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Hosting tempest plugins in a dedicated repo has been acknowledged as a community goal. If a project prefers to keep the plugin in tree there should be a strong motivation to balance the downside of being the outlier.  

For instance, Aodh service client (https://github.com/openstack/aodh/blob/master/aodh/tests/tempest/service/client.py) may be useful to write cross project integration tests - however as long as the plugin is hosted in the main project, accessing the client requires installing aodh and all of its dependencies as well.'}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2017-09-05 14:58:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> For instance, Aodh service client (https://github.com/openstack/aodh/blob/master/aodh/tests/tempest/service/client.py) may be useful to write cross project integration tests - however as long as the plugin is hosted in the main project, accessing the client requires installing aodh and all of its dependencies as well.

If we had to choose, we'd prefer to remove that client entirely and have the tests done with Gabbi, so"}, {'account_id': 1921, 'date': '2017-09-05 15:05:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

So why don't you do so? If you don't use the tests you may as well delete them.
Keeping them there and not running them will just let them bitrot anyways."}, {'account_id': 1921, 'date': '2017-09-05 15:09:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

That does not play well with cross-project alignment though: if someone from another community approaches OpenStack to write some OpenStack - community X integration tests, they will have tempest clients from some projects but not for others. 

Of course this is hypothetical so it probably makes sense to wait and see if the use case is there  then you can implement the tempest client.'}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2017-09-05 15:34:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> So why don't you do so? If you don't use the tests you may as well delete them.

Why don't YOU do so? ;)"}, {'account_id': 1955, 'date': '2017-09-13 11:07:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Generic tempest plugin for Gabbi tests looks like a good idea.

For migration from the current aodh tempest plugin, do we know where is it used? Those places would have to be modified anyway if aodh tempest plugin is moved to a separate repo, so could be migrated to the generic gabbi tempest plugin instead.'}, {'account_id': 12393, 'date': '2017-09-14 08:47:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> Generic tempest plugin for Gabbi tests looks like a good idea.
 > 
 > For migration from the current aodh tempest plugin, do we know
 > where is it used?

Currently, Aodh tempest plugin is used in Ceilometer and Congress Scenario tempest tests:
* http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/ceilometer/tree/ceilometer/tests/tempest/scenario/test_telemetry_integration.py
* http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/congress/tree/congress_tempest_tests/tests/scenario/congress_datasources/test_aodh.py

Apart from that Heat and Vitrage has aodh tests, does not depends on Aodh tempest plugin.
* https://github.com/openstack/heat/blob/master/heat_integrationtests/scenario/test_aodh_alarm.py
* http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/vitrage/tree/vitrage_tempest_tests/tests/api/datasources/test_aodh.py

 > Those places would have to be modified anyway if
 > aodh tempest plugin is moved to a separate repo, so could be
 > migrated to the generic gabbi tempest plugin instead.

So few questions here:
* Are we planning to remove tempest plugins from Aodh, gnoochi, ceilometer and panko?
* if tempest plugin got removed, switch to gabbi-tempest plugin for the same?'}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2017-09-14 14:12:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> Are we planning to remove tempest plugins from Aodh, gnoochi, ceilometer and panko?

Depends on what you mean by "we" and "plan". :)

The plan is to keep using Gabbi and its interface with Tempest.

If the interface can be made generic and live outside the projects, we'll be more than happy. If we can then ditch the poor native-Tempest tests there is, cherry on the cake. :)'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2017-09-29 16:59:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

We have moved to Zuul v3 now, this change needs to be done differently
now, for current status and more information, see
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-September/122834.html'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2017-10-29 14:15:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

We have switched to Zuul v3 now, this change does not apply anymore.

Learn on how to update your change with Zuul v3 at
https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/zuulv3.html .

Simplified:
* Job definitions can be in-repo; common job definitions are in
  openstack-infra/openstack-zuul-jobs repository
* Job scheduling can be done in-repo for project specific changes,
  common jobs are configured via
  openstack-infra/project-config/zuul.d/projects.yaml

Read the above mentioned document for finer details.

Please decide whether this change is still needed and then adopt if
for Zuul v3 or abandon it.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2017-11-28 10:01:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Corresponding governance change was abandoned due to lack of support from PTL, I suggest this one is abandoned as well'}, {'account_id': 12393, 'date': '2017-11-30 04:17:59.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Abandoning currently need to explore gabbi to use with tempest'}]

commit_message:
Add new repo for aodh tempest plugin

In addition to fulfilling Queens Goal "Split Tempest Plugins into Separate
Repos/Projects", this will allow us to re-enable the pbr's autodoc
building for the tempest plugin, which is currently disabled because the
oslo config option registration conflicts with the oslo configs from the
main project.

This imports from a temporary github repo that preserves the history of
the plugin and additionally applies the openstack cookiecutter to it.

[1.] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/queens/split-tempest-plugins.html

Needed-By: Icb67ff7e8ba295e33710c059b4fede14740dbeee

Change-Id: Ia9736e1700fa77cc50061998da84540f57a6f83f

[{'created': '2017-11-28 19:20:06.000000000', 'message': 'Fix neutron agent start order

In the baremetal deployment, we used to ensure that neutron-server was
started prior to starting up the various agents. In the containerized
deployment we need to ensure that we launch the agents after the server
has been started. We can do this by configuring a start_order for each
of the services.

It should be noted that the ovs agent was actually configured to start
in step5 due to previous race conditions under HA deployments. This
change also moves ovs back to step5.

Change-Id: I3794400ef5c8ae620961914831ff85e3438b0399
Closes-Bug: #1734976
Related-Bug: #1663273
'}, {'created': '2017-11-28 20:44:10.000000000', 'message': 'Fix neutron agent start order

In the baremetal deployment, we used to ensure that neutron-server was
started prior to starting up the various agents. In the containerized
deployment we need to ensure that we launch the agents after the server

It should be noted that the ovs agent was actually configured to start
in step5 on baremetal due to previous race conditions under HA

Change-Id: I3794400ef5c8ae620961914831ff85e3438b0399

commit_message:
Fix neutron agent start order

In the baremetal deployment, we used to ensure that neutron-server was
started prior to starting up the various agents. In the containerized
deployment we need to ensure that we launch the agents after the server
has been started. We can do this by configuring a start_order for each
of the services.

It should be noted that the ovs agent was actually configured to start
in step5 on baremetal due to previous race conditions under HA
deployments. This change leaves it in step4 but configures the
start_order to be after the neutron-api service.

Change-Id: I3794400ef5c8ae620961914831ff85e3438b0399
Closes-Bug: #1734976
Related-Bug: #1663273

commit_message:
Enable some off-by-default checks

Some of available checks are disabled by default,
like:[H106] Dont put vim configuration in source
files[H203] Use assertIs(Not)None to check for None

Change-Id: I3891fb42fe26d0edfbf85fddd2da5d8ff7739202
story: 2001301
task: 5852

commit_message:
Update devstack plugin and examples

The devstack plugin should only use the openstackclient to
interact with OpenStack services via CLI.

This patch fixes both the devstack plugin and the examples.

Task: 5678
Task: 5680
Task: 5698
Story: 2001183

Change-Id: Id30ab0484edb350f0a424a0fc90c381357614b8e

This fixes a regression which reintroduced bug #1640449 because

commit_message:
Select first node as bootstrap node not using name

This fixes a regression which reintroduced bug #1640449 because
we hard-code the node index/name instead of sorting the map of servers

Conflicts:
	common/deploy-steps.j2

Change-Id: Iaffc66a41edf176dde3b5adf603a9cff6db7aa24

commit_message:
Set notification_format to 'unversioned'

Currently there is no consumer for the versioned notification format,
which results in messages queueing up for infinite time.  Until we
have a consumer for the 'versioned' format, we set it to
'unversioned'.

Closes-Bug: #1734185
Depends-On: Id08b2d5a1e87825b182e767bffc4c15e5ce9968f
Change-Id: I5be547acbd1245de42572941d2185863697f89bd
(cherry picked from commit 1624e1cf19b19b4342fe143753df1fa030593294)

fully qualified domain name.

2. https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1507888

commit_message:
Do not set dhcp_domain in Nova from overcloud_domain_name

The dhcp_domain option was deprecated in Pike [1] and is causing
issues like [2] by configuring the shortname of nodes to their
fully qualified domain name.

1. https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/stable/pike/nova/conf/network.py#L468
2. https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1507888

Closes-Bug: 1733874
Change-Id: I4db66155b2c4ba8e0639ec00f938a8bc2ac85762
(cherry picked from commit e29de0a58c254b41d0c562fb09cbdab224cb70bc)

commit_message:
Add ComputeAlt role and environment

In order to support compute services ppc64le, which currently don't
have supported methods for building and distributing container images,
we create a role 'ComputeAlt' which directly uses the puppet/services
templates to configure services that would typically be containers.

This new role is supposed to minimally diverge from the Compute role

The following services have been switch for the puppet versions:
 - OS::TripleO::Services::ComputeCeilometerAgent
 - OS::TripleO::Services::ComputeNeutronOvsAgent
 - OS::TripleO::Services::Iscsid
 - OS::TripleO::Services::NovaCompute
 - OS::TripleO::Services::NovaLibvirt
 - OS::TripleO::Services::NovaMigrationTarget

The following services have been removed as they're only available as
docker containers:
 - OS::TripleO::Services::Docker
 - OS::TripleO::Services::ContainersLogrotateCrond
 - OS::TripleO::Services::RsyslogSidecar

Alternate versions for the following services are configured, they are
left as OS::Heat::None the operator will need to define them
appropriately if they're needed:
 - OS::TripleO::Services::Collectd
 - OS::TripleO::Services::Fluentd
 - OS::TripleO::Services::SensuClient
 - OS::TripleO::Services::OVNController

Change-Id: I31d673dd048f687c9125733a77d0c9e6069e0614

commit_message:
Populate container fields for new container

We are going to list container fields directly from DB [1].
Therefore, we needs populate information into the container
record right after it is created.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/522433/

Change-Id: I4b86877f7671c8b7146e2dedbc6fb14e98916840
Related-Bug: #1733765

commit_message:
[WIP] Add cross cells support for InstanceActionAPI

This patch we teach InstanceActionAPI about cells.

We get the cell info from instance mappings tables using the
instance UUID which the user given, and then we set target
cell for every method of InstanceActionAPI to teach them to know
the right cell to be accessed.

Change-Id: I7e95f38b1b69aecd21a63ea010d20ca30bb1f80f

commit_message:
Protect rootwrap daemon socket against multiple threads

Wrap the call with eventlet.Semaphore. Simultaneous Client.execute
calls can fail badly. Alternatively, rootwrap daemon connections
could be made every time when Client.execute is called, without
using a semaphore.

Change-Id: Id9d38832c67f2d81d382cda797a48fee943a27f1
Closes-bug: #1654287
(cherry picked from commit 7711a6ce31c3ffa8249bfeac53a4d9e306a7299f)

commit_message:
Replace jsonutils by common json package

Should remove oslo.serialization which only use at one test-case.
This change will help project do not depends this package,
and let's use the regular json attribute anyway.

Change-Id: I051fcf749970b52923180d054a13ca889acbcc30

The docs CI job is failing on trying to run tox -evenv to run build
sphinx. However this job was not defined anywhere. THis commit adds the
job definition to hopefully unbreak the job. To enable the jobs to work
we also need to install the sphinx deps to build the docs. This was
previously done in the tox.ini but this commit moves it to
test-requirements.txt to ensure that all the tox jobs are able to build
docs.

Change-Id: I5457f3e442fe673a81925a8ed2f36f4eab0639cb
'}]
commit_message:
Add a venv tox job

The docs CI job is failing on trying to run tox -evenv to run build
sphinx. However this job was not defined anywhere. THis commit adds the
job definition to hopefully unbreak the job. To enable the jobs to work
we also need to install the sphinx deps to build the docs. This was
previously done in the tox.ini but this commit moves it to
test-requirements.txt to ensure that all the tox jobs are able to build
docs.

Change-Id: I5457f3e442fe673a81925a8ed2f36f4eab0639cb

commit_message:
Zuul: add file extension to playbook path

Zuul now supports including the file extension on the playbook path
and omitting the extension is now deprecrated.  Update references
to include the extension.

Change-Id: I60d9a92683bc7ec5f9ef204f147a18de9c99e9c7

It has to be reviewed with https://review.openstack.org/#/c/523854/  in mind."}, {'account_id': 538, 'date': '2017-11-29 13:25:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2

Okay, that makes sense when discussed in the context of 523854. It might have been nice to see that relation in the commit message. ;)

I'm okay with this, but we should probably follow up with a release note here."}, {'account_id': 23163, 'date': '2017-11-29 13:26:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> > > Do we have a bug for this somewhere? I'm generally against
 > > opening
 > > > access to things (especially xinetd services) up to everything,
 > > but
 > > > if this is causing problems and we have compensating controls,
 > I
 > > > could be persuaded.
 > > >
 > > > I'm with Markos on this one -- I'd like to understand the 'why'
 > > > before putting a deuce on this patch. ;)
 > >
 > > It's broken in master of the integrated gates...
 > 
 > It has to be reviewed with https://review.openstack.org/#/c/523854/
 >  in mind.

OK that^ patch locks it down properly but why opening it up in the first place? We are going to override it anyway. And so will the deployers. I guess because the original code in this role is a bit too complex to follow it? Would it make more sense to use 127.0.0.1 instead so we sort of 'force' people to override it instead of keeping it to 0.0.0.0/0 by accident?"}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2017-11-29 13:38:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 538, 'date': '2017-11-29 13:39:09.000000000', 'content': 'Removed Workflow+1 by Major Hayden <major@mhtx.net>

Currently the integrated build fails with the existing value
of galera_monitoring_allowed_source.

This can be simplified while still staying secure by default
by giving no access to the xinetd service, unless explicitly
defined.

The xinetd whitelist can accept hostnames, so we document this

commit_message:
Fix galera_monitoring_allowed_source

Currently the integrated build fails with the existing value
of galera_monitoring_allowed_source.

This can be simplified while still staying secure by default
by giving no access to the xinetd service, unless explicitly
defined.

The xinetd whitelist can accept hostnames, so we document this
feature in defaults, and simplify the role.

Change-Id: Ibb2c5b90c79899036e5bcf9717a3b51cf5ec6b70

commit_message:
Remove useless configuration samples from the installation document

This patch removes configuration samples which are not changed from
default values.

Users are expected to see configuration docs [1] if they want to
change them.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/blazar/latest/configuration/index.html

Change-Id: Iea33ea47c31a1e265bb30e513c6f379d0ac3743c

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-07-06 22:46:41.000000000', 'message': "DVR: Fix binding info for DVR port not found error

Recently we have been seeing an error in neutron associated
with DVR routers, that says 'Binding info for DVR port not
found'.
This error is thrown when the 'get_bound_port_context' is
called when trying to notify_l2pop_port_wiring.
notify_l2pop_port_wiring is intended for router 'HA' ports, so
the get_bound_port_context should be called here only for 'HA'
ports.

This was introduced by a recent refactor in neutron
Icd4cd4e3f735e88299e86468380c5f786e7628fe

Change-Id: I1c636344068518aa26be6c96c598c61b7f0f3563
Closes-Bug: #1702769

commit_message:
DVR: Fix binding info for DVR port not found error

Recently we have been seeing an error in neutron associated
with DVR routers, that says 'Binding info for DVR port not
found'.
This error is thrown when the 'get_bound_port_context' is
called when trying to notify_l2pop_port_wiring.
notify_l2pop_port_wiring is intended for router 'HA' ports, so
the get_bound_port_context should be called here only for 'HA'
ports.

This was introduced by a recent refactor in neutron
Icd4cd4e3f735e88299e86468380c5f786e7628fe

Change-Id: I1c636344068518aa26be6c96c598c61b7f0f3563
Closes-Bug: #1702769

commit_message:
Enable gentoo in pip-and-virtualenv element

Currently it will hit the `else` and try to apt-get, which fails.

Change-Id: I951882cf3897ced165e167f12877c05ee62a5054

[{'created': '2017-11-15 20:01:56.000000000', 'message': 'Release new oslo.rootwrap for Queens

The release contains a fix for a bug that should help neutron fullstack
gate. (The bug is when a timeout during a command execution leaves stale
data in the rootwrap daemon socket, and the data is then returned to the
next caller instead of being flushed.)

Change-Id: I87642f3105803ec2cc7bd3d5ac119c29db70697f
Related-Bug: #1654287
'}, {'created': '2017-11-15 20:49:35.000000000', 'message': 'Release new oslo.rootwrap for Queens

The release contains a fix for a bug that should help neutron fullstack
gate. (The bug is when a timeout during a command execution leaves stale
data in the rootwrap daemon socket, and the data is then returned to the
next caller instead of being flushed.)

The minor version number is bumped because the release contains

Change-Id: I87642f3105803ec2cc7bd3d5ac119c29db70697f
Related-Bug: #1654287
'}]
commit_message:
Release new oslo.rootwrap for Queens

The release contains a fix for a bug that should help neutron fullstack
gate. (The bug is when a timeout during a command execution leaves stale
data in the rootwrap daemon socket, and the data is then returned to the
next caller instead of being flushed.)

The minor version number is bumped because the release contains
requirements changes.

Change-Id: I87642f3105803ec2cc7bd3d5ac119c29db70697f
Related-Bug: #1654287

- gate-tripleo-ci-centos-7-ovb-ha-oooq http://logs.openstack.org/13/489013/17/check-tripleo/gate-tripleo-ci-centos-7-ovb-ha-oooq/b1ba4a4/ : SUCCESS in 2h 34m 49s'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2017-08-09 03:42:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 17: Code-Review-1

This still seems to miss the debian-minimal path (would not be necessary in debian element as it uses it).  also misses gentoo, but not sure if it's a problem there

the fact that we're missing things and have no visibility in tests is a red flag that maybe we should keep thinking about this.

I am still quite unclear on the root cause of all this.  Why is any baseline image we are using to build coming with an /etc/machine-id already in it?  Maybe there are valid reasons to be robust against this, but it's never been a problem before so I would like to be very clear on why it has become a problem now.

If it is appearing during -minimal type builds (which I don't believe it does) then that would probably indicate another bug we should investigate.  Maybe, if we understand that, this should just be an element like vm/bootloader that is generically added on, and documented as to when you need it.

> Are we running virt-sysprep on the RHEL/CentOS/Fedora/Ubuntu/Debian/Opensuse cloud images?

no"}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2017-08-30 04:22:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17:

further to irc conversation, from my reading of [1] udevadm settle --timeout=0 should fall through with EXIT_FAILURE if the queue is not empty and the deadline is 0 (the man page wasn't explicit on this).  Thus it could be used as a check as described, which would be good to confirm this is really our problem.

also, as discussed the "udevadm settle --timeout=10 --exit-if-exists=${DEV}" does, I guess, do the same thing anyway.  It has a one-second loop and just checks access() on the device

[1] https://github.com/systemd/systemd/blob/master/src/udev/udevadm-settle.c'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2017-08-30 04:22:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 17:

^ that was obviously meant for another bug

but i've been looking at this too :)"}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2017-09-15 00:55:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17:

So for reference, at least on RH platforms, if systemd is installed (minimal builds ... or re-installed for image-based builds) the .spec file creates a /etc/machine-id.

for some reason, /bin/kernel-install wants to use the machine-id, and on later versions of Fedora (26) actualy fails without a non-blank version [1].  so we may want to add *and* remove it


[1] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1486124'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2017-09-15 04:11:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17:

recheck

want to see the result of this with newly merged bits'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-09-15 05:00:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17:

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-07-30 18:29:05.000000000', 'message': "Remove /etc/machine-id as a final cleanup

Deploying many nodes with the generated image shouldn't have the same
/etc/machine-id .

Change-Id: I73d0577d31464521b3989312fd9d982a1312a268
"}, {'created': '2017-07-30 18:48:48.000000000', 'message': "Remove /etc/machine-id as a final cleanup

Deploying many nodes with the generated image shouldn't have the same
/etc/machine-id so clearing it and letting systemd generate a new
id upon first boot seems to be the best way to achieve this.

Change-Id: I73d0577d31464521b3989312fd9d982a1312a268
"}, {'created': '2017-07-30 18:49:26.000000000', 'message': "Clear /etc/machine-id to avoid duplicate machine-ids

Deploying many nodes with the generated image shouldn't have the same
/etc/machine-id so clearing it and letting systemd generate a new
id upon first boot seems to be the best way to achieve this.

Change-Id: I73d0577d31464521b3989312fd9d982a1312a268
"}, {'created': '2017-07-30 18:50:50.000000000', 'message': "Clear /etc/machine-id to avoid duplicate machine-ids

Deploying many nodes with the generated image shouldn't have the same
/etc/machine-id so clearing it and letting systemd generate a new
id upon first boot seems to be the best way to achieve this.

Change-Id: I73d0577d31464521b3989312fd9d982a1312a268

"}, {'created': '2017-07-31 19:14:32.000000000', 'message': "Clear /etc/machine-id to avoid duplicate machine-ids

Deploying many nodes with the generated image shouldn't have the same
/etc/machine-id so clearing it and letting systemd generate a new
id upon first boot seems to be the best way to achieve this.

commit_message:
Clear /etc/machine-id to avoid duplicate machine-ids

Deploying many nodes with the generated image shouldn't have the same
/etc/machine-id so clearing it and letting systemd generate a new
id upon first boot seems to be the best way to achieve this.

Change-Id: I73d0577d31464521b3989312fd9d982a1312a268
Closes-bug: 1707526
Closes-bug: 1672461

commit_message:
Make python changes more reliable

We oneshot emerge without calculating dependencies a few things to solve
for possible dependency loops.

Python 3.5 also became stable, so don't need to do special things for
it.

Matched the uninstall with the install lines (no need for a full if
statement).

Change-Id: I7c5e546612ac47d659e73a46a52e34d39ca81949

commit_message:
Catch attrbute error for other APIs

Depending on the failure, ironic can return what
gets translated to unicode, which can generate an
AttributeError when the exception attempts to be
examined to report the error, which suppresses
the original error.

Added AttributeError to the exception catch.

Change-Id: I246c2e797a7ed22f990a264856c7cbda18be7ca5

With a jetpack!'}, {'_account_id': 11904, 'name': 'Sean McGinnis', 'email': 'sean.mcginnis@gmail.com', 'username': 'SeanM'}, {'_account_id': 12597, 'name': 'Lin Yang', 'email': 'lin.a.yang@intel.com', 'username': 'lin.yang'}, {'_account_id': 13629, 'name': 'Zhipeng', 'email': 'huangzhipeng@huawei.com', 'username': 'zhipengh'}, {'_account_id': 13945, 'name': 'ZhangYang', 'email': 'wosunoozzy@gmail.com', 'username': 'WosunOoO'}, {'_account_id': 14131, 'name': 'shaohef', 'email': 'shaohe.feng@intel.com', 'username': 'shaohefeng'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 25738, 'name': 'Xinran WANG', 'email': 'xin-ran.wang@intel.com', 'username': 'Xinran'}, {'_account_id': 25906, 'name': 'leonaldo', 'email': 'lei.xiao@outlook.com'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 6610, 'date': '2017-09-29 03:30:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6610, 'date': '2017-09-29 03:32:39.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from bp/s to formal-vote'}, {'account_id': 8290, 'date': '2017-09-30 02:17:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 14131, 'date': '2017-09-30 03:07:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 8846, 'date': '2017-09-30 06:55:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 25906, 'date': '2017-09-30 06:59:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

We need it!'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2017-10-03 12:09:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I think it's a great idea, however as discussed on the ML thread (http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-September/122594.html) I think it needs to be done properly so that it doesn't turn into a maintenance nightmare. The overlap with Nova and Ironic needs to be properly studied, and some reusable libraries might be necessary to avoid code duplication and drift.

So overall I think this needs a bit more work and coordination between those 3 projects before we can make a call on official inclusion. I look forward to the discussion at the Forum in Sydney to make progress here."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2017-10-03 13:54:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1

I feel similarly to Thierry: I really want to see this happen, but we need to take care that any duplication with Nova and Ironic is effectively managed.

That doesn't have to mean that we extract and use libraries with all three. It would be, for example, perfectly reasonable to leapfrog one or some of the projects as long as the left behind project had a road to "catching up".

I mention this because given the backlog in nova's work queue, adding more to it so that Mogan can move ahead would block Mogan unnecessarily.

Would be better for Mogan to move ahead and do improvement which could potentially be eventually ported to Nova when nova is able to catch up.

It's not really clear what we are waiting for here, so unitl there's a clear expression of that, I'm +1'}, {'account_id': 25738, 'date': '2017-10-04 06:29:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 9610, 'date': '2017-10-04 08:13:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2017-10-05 15:32:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote-1

I think the architecture of being close, but not exactly the nova api both to users and guests is going to cause the same level of confusion and consternation that nova-net continuing to exist while neutron was out there.'}, {'account_id': 13629, 'date': '2017-10-06 00:06:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2017-10-06 09:16:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

We should probably delay this decision until we have the planned forum session around "Bare metal as a service: Ironic vs. Mogan vs. Nova" and see if we can get them to work together in a sustainable fashion.'}, {'account_id': 6610, 'date': '2017-10-09 12:21:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@Sean Dangue, thanks for rasing that. I understand your concerns about the confusion that Mogan may bring to users. But I'm afraid that some users already got confusion with the current way to provide bare metal resources as a second class virt driver under nova. 


Unlike nova-net and neutron situation, do you think placing nova and mogan into different constellations will remove the confusion?


constellation: nova, ironic
For users who don't need the unique features, bare metals and containers are provided as compute resources like virtual machines, using same API, quota management, all in the same manner with virtual machines.


constellation: nova, ironic, mogan, zun
For users who want to manage virtual machines, bare metals, and containers as separated resources, with specific API for each to fully expose capabilities.


Not sure why Zun project not get rejected by such reason, compared with nova-docker, it's also not bounded by Nova's API."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2017-10-10 21:54:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1

We've previously said projects don't "own" a feature space, so I don't see an issue with adding a new project if the intent is to go further than the support in one of our existing projects. Experimenting with extending the APIs in this area to take advantage of differences between VMs, containers, and bare metal seems like a reasonable approach.'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2017-10-12 15:34:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

My worry here is the ecosystem cost of having two APIs to launch baremetal instances, for example all the work needed to heat to enable that part of the ecosystem, etc.

I am all for experimentation, but I worry about the community cost here.

Most of the missing features that are described seem to have a plan coming together for integration, making use of traits. Its a more cloud flavor approach, rather than a messy lots of different types of hardware exposed to users approach, as you would expect with a Nova interface. But Mogan doesn't appear to change that.

I need to give this more thought before I could vote on it properly."}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2017-10-12 16:01:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Abstaining for now. I think this is a great project with good ideas but I would like acks from Ironic folks and see what they think.
One thing which isn't clear to me from reading the commit message is:

"Mogan is dedicated to providing bare metal resources, which is suitable for bare metal cloud and cloud that provides bare metal as separated resources (...)".

What Mogan has that Nova and Ironic don't provide to the end users?
What problems are we solving in Mogan that can't be solved in Ironic and Nova?
Folks here probably know the answer, please excuse my ignorance and probably my lack of knowledge on the compute API area but I really need to understand that before I vote. I'll also look at the existing code to see what has been done.'}, {'account_id': 6610, 'date': '2017-10-13 07:08:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

"OpenStack is all about VM's. If you're not, good luck!"

I heared many concerns about leveraging OpenStack for bare metal cloud product. They'd rather use Ironic standalone with a private project like Mogan to provide bare metal as first class resources like other good IaaS services around. I don't mean Mogan is better than others, we are relatively young and apparently not offensive. The API architecture and scheduling design of Mogan may not quite fit into the bare metal world yet, it will be progressive within a baremetal-centric project.

Even though much work has been made to break out Nova's baremetal driver into the first class Ironic project, OpenStack remains extremely virtualization-centric in its design. Nova's mission is to provide any compute resources, but the reality doesn't match the promise. You always have to find a common subset of features between virtual machines and bare metals. I don't know why bare metals are inferior to virtual machines in OpenStack/IaaS services.

I don't want Mogan to be bounded by a set of partially working API, and we already recognized some bare metal specific features like RAID, partitions, and firmware management. Also we may get rid of flavor and make a inventory based scheduler later with Ironic's suggestions during the discussions on the mailing list.  And with RSD server, we can compose hardware resources on the fly, which will make the API more different.'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2017-10-17 09:43:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

So the company I work with is largely focused on baremetal Ironic + Nova clouds right now. We see our users wanting to make use of the wide ecosystem that has built up around Nova's APIs (heat, ansible support, magnum, sahara, etc), but they just ssh into a baremetal machine, rather than a VM. So for their use case, they are using them just like a VM, but it happens to be baremetal. For me this is where Nova works.

I am working right now on making Nova able to reconfigure the node when a user boots their server via Nova, i.e. choose the RAID and BIOS config by picking a different flavor. This is wanted on the extreme optimization HPC folks. It is currently planning to use custom traits to describe these problems.

Now if Mogan wants to expose baremetal multi-tenant in a different way, particularly wrt the composable hardware, very custom RAID configs, that seems like a worthy reason for a new project. Also it seems good its in Mogan and not pushed into Ironic.

At the moment, the mogan mission appears to be trying to fix the scheduling problems of having Virt and baremetal in the same region. That has largely been fixed in Pike. I think we need a clearer set of goals around what Mogan wants to be in the future.

For me, a big problem is that we are triggering the creation of a parallel ecosystem of tools. We have to be confident that is an OK thing. If Mogan has a different enough interaction model, that makes sense. One part of that is the reuse of the "ABI" between Nova and cloud-init that is being re-used in Mogan, that needs care not to damage the existing ecosystem around that interface.'}, {'account_id': 782, 'date': '2017-10-17 09:45:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote-1

Adding my vote to match the above comment.'}, {'account_id': 6610, 'date': '2017-10-17 12:34:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thanks John Garbutt for the comments!

I'm sorry if I misled you about the mission of Mogan in previous comments/discussions, maybe because I overestimated the value of fixing the scheduling problems of having Virt and baremetal in the same region. let me try to describe it again.

The mission of Mogan is just to be a baremetal-centric project to expose bare metal multi-tenant in a different way focusing on bare metal specific things like composable hardware, custom RAID configs, partitions as you mentioned above. It will be a public interface of Ironic with a flexible scheduler for bare metal resources. 

Wrt reuse of the "ABI" between Nova and cloud-init, we have started a library https://launchpad.net/os-cpu to move that code into one place. We will try to make good and useful common functionality, and if it's sustainable, Nova can make desision then.'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2017-10-18 15:54:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

While there is not ownership of feature space, I feel like we need to be mindful that overlapping goals with differing approaches naturally creates a division of resources and isolation. Having said this, it feels like Im missing context, because while Mogan has been brought up in passing to myself and others, I feel like there has not been clear cross project discussion of what teams can do for each other to work together. Perhaps Im just joining the discussion late, but it feels like were trying to explicitly compete with overlapping areas of support and focus without the big picture.

There is great value to all teams involved in reaching mutual context as to various wants/needs. Overall, the approaches may differ and there is still value in specific approaches, as long as they are not mutually exclusive. I personally feel like further dialog is needed between the teams to work together or at least with further long term mutual insight. Not just because of technical merit or need for specific processes in some cases, but to prevent the creation of engines of fragmentation. That being said, I very much support experimentation as it can have greater velocity, but I already see we are heading in different directions that will further fragmentation. If we are going to be in the same space, some aspects naturally need to be solved by working together. I somehow suspect hardware resource locking would be a good example where a single source of truth is required in this context, and without working together, then we will just create incompatibilities.

If I were to vote, I would vote -1 at this present time from the standpoint that it is vital to at least work in concert, even if projects are going to compete with different approaches to reach overlapping goals. We should at least have our orbits mapped, courses plotted, and any potential gravity assists planned as far out in advance as possible.

I welcome a dialog at the forum or even electronically if we are unable to obtain traction or consensus at the forum. I would just prefer that we also involve some of the driver teams as there is some overlap in desired bare metal interaction and possibly some bare metal cloud operators for them to bring their use context to the discussion. Im happy to raise this during next weeks Ironic meeting.'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2017-10-18 16:17:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

In addition to what Julia said, I'd like certain things clarified somewhere. Please pardon me if they're already stated somewhere.

> What Mogan has that Nova and Ironic don't provide to the end users?

This is good to specify indeed. As John noted, we're moving to a much flexible approach to scheduling with Nova, so scheduling problems are no longer an argument. If you plan on complex inventory-based scheduling (see my email to openstack-dev a few weeks ago) - that's a different story.

Something even more important for me as the PTL of Ironic: how do you plan to interact with ironic, and where do you expect to draw a line between them?"}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2017-10-18 16:20:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2017-10-18 16:40:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> While there is not ownership of feature space, I feel like we need
 > to be mindful that overlapping goals with differing approaches
 > naturally creates a division of resources and isolation. Having
 > said this, it feels like Im missing context, because while Mogan
 > has been brought up in passing to myself and others, I feel like
 > there has not been clear cross project discussion of what teams can
 > do for each other to work together. Perhaps Im just joining the
 > discussion late, but it feels like were trying to explicitly
 > compete with overlapping areas of support and focus without the big
 > picture.
 >
 > There is great value to all teams involved in reaching mutual
 > context as to various wants/needs. Overall, the approaches may
 > differ and there is still value in specific approaches, as long as
 > they are not mutually exclusive. I personally feel like further
 > dialog is needed between the teams to work together or at least
 > with further long term mutual insight. Not just because of
 > technical merit or need for specific processes in some cases, but
 > to prevent the creation of engines of fragmentation. That being
 > said, I very much support experimentation as it can have greater
 > velocity, but I already see we are heading in different directions
 > that will further fragmentation. If we are going to be in the same
 > space, some aspects naturally need to be solved by working
 > together. I somehow suspect hardware resource locking would be a
 > good example where a single source of truth is required in this
 > context, and without working together, then we will just create
 > incompatibilities.
 > 
 > If I were to vote, I would vote -1 at this present time from the
 > standpoint that it is vital to at least work in concert, even if
 > projects are going to compete with different approaches to reach
 > overlapping goals. We should at least have our orbits mapped,
 > courses plotted, and any potential gravity assists planned as far
 > out in advance as possible.
 > 
 > I welcome a dialog at the forum or even electronically if we are
 > unable to obtain traction or consensus at the forum. I would just
 > prefer that we also involve some of the driver teams as there is
 > some overlap in desired bare metal interaction and possibly some
 > bare metal cloud operators for them to bring their use context to
 > the discussion. Im happy to raise this during next weeks Ironic
 > meeting.

When we made the big tent changes, we shifted our criteria for new projects away from exclusive ownership application areas and technical merit reviews to concentrate on building good teams, defined as groups of people working together on a common goal. Some level of overlap in feature space is explicitly allowed between projects, with restrictions on "gratuitously competing or reinventing the wheel" (as we say in https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/new-projects-requirements.html). Mogan does not seem to me to be triggering that rule.

If the Mogan features aren't moving into Nova, and someone wants to work on them, and that group of people is not necessarily the same as the group working on Nova, then there isn't a problem under my interpretation of the approval criteria.

Now, my +1 should NOT be taken as an indication that I think Mogan can avoid working with other teams. As you rightly point out the user experience will be better if the teams coordinate. But I also don't think it's necessary for the Mogan team to have any other team's approval on the approaches the they want to experiment with, and they shouldn't be blocked on that. They should build a successful tool and win the approval of users, without having to worry about gaining the approval of "competitors".

I'm looking forward to the outcome of the coordination session planned for the Sydney forum.'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2017-10-18 16:43:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Julia, Dmitry, there is a session on the schedule for Sydney titled "Bare metal as a service: Ironic vs. Mogan vs. Nova".  Don't let the 'vs' in the title put you off, the intent is to have exactly the conversations being talked about here.

I do think having preliminary conversations to that on the ML will at least tease out the specific points that should be addressed in the room to save time and get everyone aware of how the projects relate.

FWIW, I'm leaning +1 here but this is a case where I think we need a bit more clarity and understanding of the new project that time, and the conversations above, will bring.'}, {'account_id': 6610, 'date': '2017-10-23 09:18:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

wrt where to draw a line between Mogan and Ironic, If it's a must, I think it's just same like the line between Nova and Ironic. Mogan also aims to be an abstraction layer for bare metal provisioning/management projects like Ironic, so it's possible for MAAS and others to integrate with Mogan. We already got a Bank user who runs Mogan with a private bare metal management project, and they also want to upstream their driver.

For now, seems most of you guys have reached a consensus that Mogan is a good direction to continue to explore/experiment if our mission is to expose bare metal multi-tenant in a different way focusing on bare metal specific things like composable hardware, custom RAID configs, partitions and scheduling like Dmitry Tantsur mentioned in the ML.

Thanks Doug Hellmann for sharing the criteria for new projects and the +1. From my understanding, the application for inclusion here is just trying to address Julia Kreger's concerns for overlappings and fragmentations going further. Placing Mogan under the TC/community oversight will help it better integrate with the ecosystem and avoid damaging the existing things.

The forum title "Bare metal as a service: Ironic vs. Mogan vs. Nova" is indeed a bit offensive, thanks Dean Troyer for the explanation. I remember Thierry Carrez's proposal is "discussing user need on one side , and how to best integrate with the existing pieces on the other side". In order to make the forum topic concentrate on that, can you make a preliminary decision for this application before the forum happen? I can provide more clarifications and explanations if needed, thanks all!'}, {'account_id': 6610, 'date': '2017-10-24 01:37:24.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6610, 'date': '2017-10-24 01:39:33.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from bp/s to formal-vote'}, {'account_id': 6610, 'date': '2017-10-24 01:48:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

mission statement updated.'}, {'account_id': 3211, 'date': '2017-10-24 07:53:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 14131, 'date': '2017-10-24 09:38:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 25738, 'date': '2017-10-24 09:47:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 13945, 'date': '2017-10-24 13:00:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 12597, 'date': '2017-10-25 00:04:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

The mogan's direction makes perfect sense to me. This dedicated bare metal computing service provides the possibility to integrate advanced bare metal features with OpenStack. For example, RSD (Rack Scale Design) technology allow user to consider computer, networking and storage as composable pool resource and compose bare metal on demand. However, in current openstack nova and ironic will not cover this part, like compose bare metal when user request one, and it's out of nova or ironic's scope. And it will be smooth and easy to add those hardware specific workflows in mogan. So I +1 here."}, {'account_id': 8846, 'date': '2017-10-25 02:56:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11536, 'date': '2017-10-25 03:12:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 9610, 'date': '2017-10-25 06:00:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2017-11-09 07:18:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

The forum session <https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/SYD-forum-baremetal-ironic-mogan-nova> was frustrating and I don't think was able to really help move the discussion here forward in any substantial way. After an initial introduction of Mogan, the conversation turned to typically dominant members of the community who frequently speak to one another in IRC speaking to one another in the room to discuss solving problems in Nova and Ironic (and not Mogan) while other people listened. Various folk (myself included) tried to bring things to a more inclusive mode of conversation without success.

A few observations I was able to make:

* At least one operator wants to ensure that the nova api (and even the specific command 'nova boot') remains the central focus for booting any kind of compute resources (be it VM or baremetal). In a sense, this prevents opportunities for a diversity of or experimentation with implementation.

* Even if Nova and Ironic are able to work together to solve the composable hardware use case, it seems quite likely that it would take some considerable time -- _even if_ the resources currently devoted to Mogan were devoted to Nova and Ironic -- simply because of review bandwidth and velocity within Nova.

* The way that nova and ironic interoperate is consistently expressed as bad design. Why can't Mogan be the avenue to fix that? Why do we need to protect and or preserve Nova in this domain?

* The plan that Mogan reimplement a clone, with slight differences, of the Nova API as a way of implementing their solution strikes me as a bad one. It opens up the door to questions of "why don't we just do this in nova" and presumes that the nova api is the ideal solution to the Mogan use cases. It might make more sense to decouple the API from the solution, build the solution and see what API emerges that best expresses the needs of the users.

* In general decoupling the API from the implementation is likely a good idea, especially if it allows innovation in the implementations.

* Long term I'd like to see the nova api become a behind-the-scenes API, one not commonly used by new "users". If that were to happen, then the upper layer compute API could communicate with Nova, Ironic, Mogan (and presumably Neutron and Cinder and Glance too) itself, rather than Nova being a weird combo of captain and middleman.

As things stand there's no clear way for Mogan to move forward here. We need to re-evaluate and re-plan in the face of the failure to gain traction in Sydney. I think that can be done by focusing on the use cases and _why_ those uses cases cannot or should not be solved by Ironic and Nova. If that can be demonstrated there might be something here.'}, {'account_id': 6610, 'date': '2017-11-15 03:16:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

hi all, here is the comparison document of nova and mogan which was not complete during the session thus bring many confusions.

Features that are not available or do not work well in Nova+Baremetal scenario: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1Q4EEpeztyLKTwvq9UIqQraU1A1bhaiWD9wwcjfYFIW4/edit?usp=sharing'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2017-11-16 14:55:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I agree with Chris analysis. My view is:

1/ Due to the complex overlap with Nova, it is too early to consider this for official addition. It is definitely time however to dive into that overlap and difference. We need to see if Nova and Mogan really serve two different scenarios and therefore both make sense as coexisting OpenStack components

2/ If at the end of this analysis Mogan's scope ends up being sufficiently different (and/or Nova is not interested in covering that diff) then Mogan would "fit" in the picture and the main objection to its addition would be raised

3/ As Chris said, building Mogan on top of a Nova API fork is likely the wrong approach, leading to all sorts of questions. Mogan should be defined based on what the users want to do (rather than as a slightly-modified baremetal-specific Nova with a couple of additional features). That would be more compelling. We'd not focus as much on whether the difference justifies its existence.'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2017-11-16 15:45:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Zhengou, Thank you for posting an updated summary. I found the side by side comparison of the endpoints useful, but the summary also provides insight into the plans of Mogan. The one thing I feel like Im lacking a solid understanding of what is presently in Mogan, and what is planned to be in Mogan. I am unclear on this since both seem to be present on the list without clear indication. I would love to be able to provide feedback and ask a few questions on a couple of your items when you have some time available.

Aside from the comparison, I believe the session in Sydney was good to try and establish context and work through the some of the various aspects of contention to gain a better understanding, even if it was somewhat frustrating at the same time. As I see it, there is there is going to be contention because many of us have strong feelings as to the direction of various components. That being said, I do think we, myself included, failed to listen. At the same time I think we also incorrectly expected the same level of interaction and discussion that we are used to when any population of Nova and Ironic people get into a room.

Changing back to the topic of Mogan, from the standpoint of encouraging and driving forth features and functionality, I still believe there is great potential in some of the features Mogan desires to deliver in providing better access to bare metal resources and do agree with some of the necessity of such, but the fragmentation and overlap concerns weigh heavily on my mind.

Given, my history with Ironic along with my stated hopes and dreams for it, I believe I should abstain at this time.'}, {'account_id': 6610, 'date': '2017-11-17 09:09:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Thanks Julia, seems I forgot to make you can comment with the shareable link. Please have a try later :)
And really appreciate if you can give some feedback!

 > fragmentation and overlap concerns weigh heavily on my mind.
 > 
 > Given, my history with Ironic along with my stated hopes and dreams
 > for it, I believe I should abstain at this time.'}, {'account_id': 970, 'date': '2017-11-17 21:53:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I understand and agree with the stated desire for a single top-level "compute-resource create" command for users, however, "nova boot" and/or "openstack server create" is not the right one.  I like Chris' idea of eventually hiding the Nova API and developing an up-front converged API for users.  This is veering directly toward the session on multi-cloud management that turned into an Oaktree session. Something Oaktree-like may be the best solution for both of those needs.

As far as Mogen itself, we need to get some clarity on plans and overlap.  I heard Ironic folk in the room talking about some of the things they want to do with Ironic being planned for Mogen, if those things get merged into Ironic how much is left in Mogen?  Is it still a sensible stand-alone thing?'}, {'account_id': 6610, 'date': '2017-11-30 01:42:04.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

withdraw the application'}]

[{'created': '2017-09-29 03:30:46.000000000', 'message': 'Mogan - Bare Metal Compute Service

Mogan[1] aims to offer bare metal as first class resources to users with
a set of bare metal specific API and a baremetal-centric scheduler.

**clarify the overlaps between Mogan and Nova**
Nova works okay with bare metals, but it's never going to work perfectly
though, because we always have to keep interoperable with virtual machines.
On the contrary, Mogan is dedicated to providing bare metal resources,
which is suitable for bare metal cloud and cloud that provides bare metal
as separated resources(most of the public cloud providers in the market
do like this). Mogan will be a good addition to OpenStack for such users.
So it's not real overlap because they are in different "constellations".

More discussions on both dev and ops mailing list can be found here[2].

Mogan project and the team follow the 4 opens:
* Open Source:
  The Mogan source code[3], specifications[4] and documentation[5][6] are
  completely open source. All are released under the Apache 2.0 licence.

* Open Design:
  The team openly works for all activities. We have weekly team meetings[7]
  at #openstack-meeting, and report project's priorities to the dev mailing
  list every week based on the whiteboard[8]. Additionally, we have organized
  a virtual Queens PTG[9].

* Open Development:
  All Mogan code is reviewed and hosted in OpenStack CI[10]. The CI
  supports unit tests, functional tests and Tempest scenario test.
  All blueprints and bugs are tracked by Launchpad[11].

* Open Community:
  All new design and bugs are open in Mogan launchpad[11]. The project
  IRC channel #openstack-mogan is open to everyone. We have also selected
  the PTL and core reviewers by contributors[12] publicly.

1. https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Mogan
2. http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-September/122594.html
3. https://github.com/openstack/mogan
4. https://github.com/openstack/mogan-specs
5. http://mogan.readthedocs.io/en/latest/
6. http://mogan.readthedocs.io/projects/api-ref/en/latest/
7. http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/mogan/
8. https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/MoganWhiteBoard
9. https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/mogan-queens-ptg
10. https://review.openstack.org/#/q/mogan
11. https://launchpad.net/mogan
12. http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-August/120572.html

Change-Id: Iaab3c426e2d60b01b0cca44ccf20957101ede805

commit_message:
Mogan - Bare Metal Compute Service

Mogan[1] aims to offer bare metal as first class resources to users with
a set of bare metal specific API and a baremetal-centric scheduler.

**clarify the overlaps between Mogan and Nova**
Nova works okay with bare metals, but it's never going to work perfectly
though, because we always have to keep interoperable with virtual machines.
On the contrary, Mogan is dedicated to providing bare metal resources,
which is suitable for bare metal cloud and cloud that provides bare metal
as separated resources(most of the public cloud providers in the market
do like this). Mogan will be a good addition to OpenStack for such users.
So it's not real overlap because they are in different "constellations".

More discussions on both dev and ops mailing list can be found here[2].

Mogan project and the team follow the 4 opens:
* Open Source:
  The Mogan source code[3], specifications[4] and documentation[5][6] are
  completely open source. All are released under the Apache 2.0 licence.

* Open Design:
  The team openly works for all activities. We have weekly team meetings[7]
  at #openstack-meeting, and report project's priorities to the dev mailing
  list every week based on the whiteboard[8]. Additionally, we have organized
  a virtual Queens PTG[9].

* Open Development:
  All Mogan code is reviewed and hosted in OpenStack CI[10]. The CI
  supports unit tests, functional tests and Tempest scenario test.
  All blueprints and bugs are tracked by Launchpad[11].

* Open Community:
  All new design and bugs are open in Mogan launchpad[11]. The project
  IRC channel #openstack-mogan is open to everyone. We have also selected
  the PTL and core reviewers by contributors[12] publicly.

1. https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Mogan
2. http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-September/122594.html
3. https://github.com/openstack/mogan
4. https://github.com/openstack/mogan-specs
5. http://mogan.readthedocs.io/en/latest/
6. http://mogan.readthedocs.io/projects/api-ref/en/latest/
7. http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/mogan/
8. https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/MoganWhiteBoard
9. https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/mogan-queens-ptg
10. https://review.openstack.org/#/q/mogan
11. https://launchpad.net/mogan
12. http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-August/120572.html

Change-Id: Iaab3c426e2d60b01b0cca44ccf20957101ede805

recheck'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2017-11-29 23:09:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I know this was asked for, but testing every element in isolation by doing an entire platform build with just that element doesn't really help that much, especially here where it's not trying to boot it.  We can't just keep multiplying out the gate testing time.  Although it would be possible to notice if we regress on the packages, that's about all we'll know.

an avenue that might work is adding this to the existing ironic-agent test.  that would bundle a few related things together and be a better approach"}, {'account_id': 26598, 'date': '2017-11-30 01:29:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> I know this was asked for, but testing every element in isolation
 > by doing an entire platform build with just that element doesn't
 > really help that much, especially here where it's not trying to
 > boot it.  We can't just keep multiplying out the gate testing time.
 >  Although it would be possible to notice if we regress on the
 > packages, that's about all we'll know.
 > 
 > an avenue that might work is adding this to the existing
 > ironic-agent test.  that would bundle a few related things together
 > and be a better approach

Got it, thanks Ian"}, {'account_id': 26598, 'date': '2017-11-30 01:30:10.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

Have tested ironic deploy on arm64 board.
deploy kernel:
DIB_RELEASE=jessie \
DIB_DEV_USER_USERNAME=linux DIB_DEV_USER_PASSWORD=arm \
DIB_DEV_USER_SHELL=/bin/bash DIB_DEV_USER_PWDLESS_SUDO=yes \
disk-image-create debian ironic-agent grub2 devuser \
-a arm64 -o deploy-jessie

working image:
DIB_RELEASE=jessie \
DIB_DEV_USER_USERNAME=linux DIB_DEV_USER_PASSWORD=arm \
DIB_DEV_USER_SHELL=/bin/bash DIB_DEV_USER_PWDLESS_SUDO=yes \
disk-image-create debian baremetal grub2 devuser dhcp-all-interfaces \
-a arm64 -o image-jessie

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/512174/

[{'created': '2017-10-16 05:40:37.000000000', 'message': 'Fix grub2 dependency on arm64

Unable to locate package reported when
DIB_RELEASE=jessie disk-image-create debian ironic-agent \
grub2 devuser -a arm64 -o deploy-jessie

E: Unable to locate package grub-pc-bin
E: Unable to locate package shim-signed
E: Unable to locate package grub-efi-amd64-signed

Fix the issue via adding arch dependency and arm64 packages

Change-Id: I40650a887b575a9c2b00a8c5036c35354d548673
Signed-off-by: Zhangfei Gao <zhangfei.gao@linaro.org>
'}]
commit_message:
Fix grub2 dependency on arm64

Unable to locate package reported when
DIB_RELEASE=jessie disk-image-create debian ironic-agent \
grub2 devuser -a arm64 -o deploy-jessie

E: Unable to locate package grub-pc-bin
E: Unable to locate package shim-signed
E: Unable to locate package grub-efi-amd64-signed

Fix the issue via adding arch dependency and arm64 packages

Change-Id: I40650a887b575a9c2b00a8c5036c35354d548673
Signed-off-by: Zhangfei Gao <zhangfei.gao@linaro.org>

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-06-26 21:29:05.000000000', 'message': 'User Management of TOTP credentials

/v1/EditMFA/
GET:
- Shows whether or not the user has it enabled
POST:
- Adds TOTP-draft credenatials to the current user
DELETE:
- Removes MFA from current user (after token submit)

Both the POST and the DELETE, return a token ID, the POST also
returns a provisioning URI for use with authentication apps
such as Google Authenticator. The token must be submitted with
a correct TOTP passcode (for the users account), before any
changes occur.

Change-Id: Iaf1b9412a97fa6d8bd3f90381e1ff34449c78e8d
'}]
commit_message:
User Management of TOTP credentials

/v1/EditMFA/
GET:
- Shows whether or not the user has it enabled
POST:
- Adds TOTP-draft credenatials to the current user
DELETE:
- Removes MFA from current user (after token submit)

Both the POST and the DELETE, return a token ID, the POST also
returns a provisioning URI for use with authentication apps
such as Google Authenticator. The token must be submitted with
a correct TOTP passcode (for the users account), before any
changes occur.

Change-Id: Iaf1b9412a97fa6d8bd3f90381e1ff34449c78e8d

commit_message:
Release os-brick 2.1.1

This is a small big fix to catch a change that makes
close of cryptsetup volumes idempotent.  This should
have gone along with the earlier change for luks.

Change-Id: I6cd15c41cb975b6910c2728cd5d45d63243ac697

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-07-05 16:45:04.000000000', 'message': 'Revert "Fix #1627402: fix grub2 element for ubuntu xenial"

This reverts commit 003fc17208e645b453ccb7c7ad27d332bdae490c.

It seems this special handling is still needed. The following command fails with the error of "/usr/sbin/grub-probe: error: cannot find a device for / (is /dev mounted?)". I can post a full log if needed.

$ disk-image-create -o ubuntu.qcow2 ubuntu grub2

I can post a full log if necessary, although the above should be sufficient for a dev to reproduce. I also confirmed that reverting this change (adding the special handling back) fixes the image building.

Change-Id: Ieb828a7861249044ce0ed1eb36d089d81992efd0
'}, {'created': '2017-07-05 21:50:23.000000000', 'message': 'Revert "Fix #1627402: fix grub2 element for ubuntu xenial"

commit_message:
Revert "Fix #1627402: fix grub2 element for ubuntu xenial"

This reverts commit 003fc17208e645b453ccb7c7ad27d332bdae490c.

It seems this special handling is still needed. The following command fails with the error of "/usr/sbin/grub-probe: error: cannot find a device for / (is /dev mounted?)". I can post a full log if needed.

$ disk-image-create -o ubuntu.qcow2 ubuntu grub2

I can post a full log if necessary, although the above should be sufficient for a dev to reproduce. I also confirmed that reverting this change (adding the special handling back) fixes the image building.

Change-Id: Ieb828a7861249044ce0ed1eb36d089d81992efd0

commit_message:
Add debian minimal requirement for arm64

Debian system building fails, fixed by adding arm64 package.

DIB_RELEASE=jessie disk-image-create debian ironic-agent \
    grub2 devuser -a arm64 -o deploy-jessie
dib-run-parts Running /tmp/dib_build.v5FEtaKx/hooks/cleanup.d/99-extract-kernel-and-ramdisk
ls: cannot access /tmp/dib_build.v5FEtaKx/mnt/boot/vmlinu*: No such file or directory

Change-Id: I610d767785df49fed954f12854be5ae78ff9baa6
Signed-off-by: Zhangfei Gao <zhangfei.gao@linaro.org>

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-16 20:06:41.000000000', 'message': 'Protect rootwrap daemon socket against multiple threads

Wrap the call with eventlet.Semaphore. Simultaneous Client.execute
calls can fail badly. Alternatively, rootwrap daemon connections
could be made every time when Client.execute is called, without
using a semaphore.

Change-Id: Id9d38832c67f2d81d382cda797a48fee943a27f1
Closes-bug: #1654287
(cherry picked from commit 7711a6ce31c3ffa8249bfeac53a4d9e306a7299f)
'}]
commit_message:
Protect rootwrap daemon socket against multiple threads

Wrap the call with eventlet.Semaphore. Simultaneous Client.execute
calls can fail badly. Alternatively, rootwrap daemon connections
could be made every time when Client.execute is called, without
using a semaphore.

Change-Id: Id9d38832c67f2d81d382cda797a48fee943a27f1
Closes-bug: #1654287
(cherry picked from commit 7711a6ce31c3ffa8249bfeac53a4d9e306a7299f)

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-08-30 16:04:53.000000000', 'message': "Handle issues with Ironic Inspector more gracefully

Until now, when the Ironic Inspector service is not reachable, the
nodes page would fail to load any nodes.

Most info about nodes can still be obtained via the Ironic service even
when the Inspector services is unavailable. In that case, this change
ensures that the nodes page loads any nodes, and displays the
introspection status of 'Unknown'.

Change-Id: I56d96928d40389045f592f314395ba38c8858877
Closes-bug: #1703614
"}]
commit_message:
Handle issues with Ironic Inspector more gracefully

Until now, when the Ironic Inspector service is not reachable, the
nodes page would fail to load any nodes.

Most info about nodes can still be obtained via the Ironic service even
when the Inspector services is unavailable. In that case, this change
ensures that the nodes page loads any nodes, and displays the
introspection status of 'Unknown'.

Change-Id: I56d96928d40389045f592f314395ba38c8858877
Closes-bug: #1703614

commit_message:
Remove unnecessary self.flags and ConfPatcher

In 'start_service' of nova.test.TestCase,
there is the following statement.

self.useFixture(nova_fixtures.ConfPatcher(host=host))

So it is not necessary to set the 'host' parameter
in configuration in the outside of 'start_service'.

TrivialFix
Change-Id: I01e20309df39b24edef91675d2812201d063f66e

commit_message:
Add 'all_tenants' for GET sec group api ref

GET /os-security-groups API accept 'all_tenants' [1]
as one of the query param to list all tenants sec groups.
But that is missing in api-ref [2]

..1
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/e9104dbaef9bbccc6b19811125d439fdf9558428/nova/network/security_group/neutron_driver.py#L178
https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/e9104dbaef9bbccc6b19811125d439fdf9558428/nova/compute/api.py#L5096

..2 https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/compute/#list-security-groups

Closes-Bug: #1734406

Change-Id: I2946f05716c9030f7880ac423cc64b49c04b2992

commit_message:
Add build-javascript-tarball to nodejs6-jobs template

... with file rules, so job run only when we touch:
npm-shrinkwrap.json and package.json

Change-Id: Ida7130b482de0328a5517b8fe827efaff25b9461

commit_message:
Redis replication does not work with TLS

Lets revert the tls support until we know it works.

Revert "TLS proxy for redis"

This reverts commit dc646db94395ce4ad29d430107f6cb19e7a44d31.

Change-Id: I9da91a1237709527ce42828ee413837ffff9f369

commit_message:
TLS proxy for redis

Redis does not have TLS out of the box. Let's use a proxy container for
TLS termination.

commit_message:
TLS proxy for redis

Redis does not have TLS out of the box. Let's use a proxy container for
TLS termination.

bp tls-via-certmonger

Co-Authored-By: Juan Antonio Osorio Robles <jaosorior@redhat.com>
Change-Id: Ie2ae0d048a71e1b1b4edb10c74bc0395a1a9d5c9
Depends-On: I078567c831ade540cf704f81564e2b7654c85c0b
Depends-On: Ia50933da9e59268b17f56db34d01dcc6b6c38147
(cherry picked from commit c2a93cf4c5d9d6b5ee0536380751a7a9540927cc)

- gate-tripleo-heat-templates-pep8-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/87/498487/1/check/gate-tripleo-heat-templates-pep8-ubuntu-xenial/46fc70a/ : SUCCESS in 3m 15s
- gate-tripleo-ci-centos-7-3nodes-multinode-nv http://logs.openstack.org/87/498487/1/check/gate-tripleo-ci-centos-7-3nodes-multinode-nv/47d2b3f/ : SUCCESS in 1h 42m 42s (non-voting)'}, {'account_id': 20172, 'date': '2017-09-08 14:56:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(Apologies for taking so long to take a proper look here)

So as much as I dislike having to use stunnel, that is just the way it is I guess.
My main question would be the following: in haproxy.cfg we have this snippet:
listen redis
  bind 172.16.2.5:6379 transparent
  balance first
  option tcp-check
  tcp-check send AUTH\ TKdy7ZkaqudyAX3mjxXcvq3He\r\n
  tcp-check send PING\r\n
  tcp-check expect string +PONG
  tcp-check send info\ replication\r\n
  tcp-check expect string role:master
  tcp-check send QUIT\r\n
  tcp-check expect string +OK
  server overcloud-controller-0.internalapi.localdomain 172.16.2.6:6379 check fall 5 inter 2000 rise 2
  server overcloud-controller-1.internalapi.localdomain 172.16.2.15:6379 check fall 5 inter 2000 rise 2
  server overcloud-controller-2.internalapi.localdomain 172.16.2.4:6379 check fall 5 inter 2000 rise 2

the tcp-check magic is what effectively allows haproxy to decide which one is the master.
Don't we need to tweak this since now port 6379 is over SSL? Has anyone gotten a setup like this working?


I went through the redis resource agent and I don't think it is explicitely using port 6379 to do stuff so we *should* be covered there."}, {'account_id': 13039, 'date': '2017-09-08 15:07:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@bandini: we've updated the haproxy.cfg for tls redis in Ia50933da9e59268b17f56db34d01dcc6b6c38147, see https://review.openstack.org/#/c/496616/18/manifests/haproxy.pp

The config now look like:

listen redis
  bind 172.16.2.4:6379 transparent
  balance first
  option tcp-check
  tcp-check connect ssl
  tcp-check send AUTH\ DsQfGEYmXCNBk9mkmGgZ4KR72\r\n
  tcp-check send PING\r\n
  tcp-check expect string +PONG
  tcp-check send info\ replication\r\n
  tcp-check expect string role:master
  tcp-check send QUIT\r\n
  tcp-check expect string +OK
  server overcloud-controller-0.internalapi.tripleodomain.example.com 172.16.2.9:6379 ca-file /etc/ipa/ca.crt check check-ssl fall 5 inter 2000 rise 2
  server overcloud-controller-1.internalapi.tripleodomain.example.com 172.16.2.13:6379 ca-file /etc/ipa/ca.crt check check-ssl fall 5 inter 2000 rise 2
  server overcloud-controller-2.internalapi.tripleodomain.example.com 172.16.2.11:6379 ca-file /etc/ipa/ca.crt check check-ssl fall 5 inter 2000 rise 2"}, {'account_id': 20172, 'date': '2017-09-08 15:09:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

Thanks Martin. I am clearly still catching up here :)'}, {'account_id': 20172, 'date': '2017-09-08 15:17:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-09-08 15:17:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Verified

commit_message:
Enable redis TLS proxy in HA deployments

Redis does not have TLS out of the box. Let's use a proxy container for
TLS termination.

This commit enables redis TLS proxy for the HA deployment.

bp tls-via-certmonger

Change-Id: I45e539872a03878337def33c681c4577c1a5629e

commit_message:
Add root-marker to publish-openstack-sphinx-docs-direct

We need a .root-marker in our docs directory for ensure we publish to
AFS properly. Without it, nothing will happen.

Change-Id: I138d0dd0e3572a5d4a5db1be17a8e54d2ed357e7
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-10-09 02:22:51.000000000', 'message': 'Make image name on instances panel configurable

This another performance improvement about Horizon instance panel. Currently,
Horizon is displaying image name for each instance, but it's expensive to
map the image id to image name, because Horizon need to either call
/v2/images?limit=1000&sort_key=created_at&sort_dir=desc to get "all" images
to do the mapping or get them one by one, see openstack_dashboard/api/nova.py#L135.
Obviously, both of them are expensive/heavey calls. So the idea is make it
configurable so that we can leave the option to cloud operator to decide if
the image name can be displayed or not.

Closes-Bug: #1721686

Change-Id: Ia660233ae35b966cd008598af39100ef615229d0

commit_message:
Make image name on instances panel configurable

This another performance improvement about Horizon instance panel.
Currently, Horizon is displaying image name for each instance,
but it's expensive to map the image id to image name, because
Horizon need to either call
/v2/images?limit=1000&sort_key=created_at&sort_dir=desc to get
"all" images to do the mapping or get them one by one, see
openstack_dashboard/api/nova.py#L135. Obviously, both of them
are expensive/heavey calls. So the idea is make it configurable
so that we can leave the option to cloud operator to decide if
the image name can be displayed or not.

Closes-Bug: #1721686

Change-Id: Ia660233ae35b966cd008598af39100ef615229d0
