commit_message:
Exclude rope folder from pep8 checks

some of us are using vim wich has a very popular plugin
for Python developing called rope.
rope creares a cach folder called .ropeproject in the root of the
project, sadly I don't have contoll over the location.
I would like pep8 to ignore it just as horizon does
https://github.com/openstack/horizon/blob/master/tox.ini#L119

Change-Id: I40095cf1a6332786333b193b17f7c6b99c53bbef

commit_message:
Change oslo.messaging prefetch default

In some case, Ceilometer can consume To of RAM. If batch is not enabled
the default behavior is to fetch all messages waiting in the queue.

Since I fail to change/expose this bad oslo.messaging default for us.
This change set a correct default on our side.

Change-Id: I3f4b0ef5fa90afb965e31584b34fdc30a5f4f9f1
(cherry picked from commit 18e372f26aec1b6328e218063423f8a813789fa5)

commit_message:
Change oslo.messaging prefetch default

In some case, Ceilometer can consume To of RAM. If batch is not enabled
the default behavior is to fetch all messages waiting in the queue.

Since I fail to change/expose this bad oslo.messaging default for us.
This change set a correct default on our side.

Change-Id: I3f4b0ef5fa90afb965e31584b34fdc30a5f4f9f1
(cherry picked from commit d208a7117aa5c2f08609dded5f40dddd509dfa3e)

tests to not run under python3.

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-29 17:07:56.000000000', 'message': 'report warnings when the minimum versions of dependencies change

Compute the dependency set for the python code being released and
report warnings when the minimum versions are changed. We can change
the warnings to errors in a separate patch when we are comfortable
that the logic is working properly.

Update clone_repo() to return the location where the clone was written
as a convenience to the caller.

Extract the logic for determining if a version is using
pre-versioning (alpha, beta, etc.) so it can be reused.

Change-Id: I22a2f6df7f3502e4fcbf2d61ef5fee849ab15529
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
'}, {'created': '2017-11-29 18:19:53.000000000', 'message': 'report warnings when the supported versions of dependencies change

Compute the dependency set for the python code being released and
report when the old minimum version no longer falls within the
specified range. For releases from master treat the message as an
error. For other branches treat the message as a warning.

Update clone_repo() to return the location where the clone was written
as a convenience to the caller.

Extract the logic for determining if a version is using
pre-versioning (alpha, beta, etc.) so it can be reused.

Change-Id: I22a2f6df7f3502e4fcbf2d61ef5fee849ab15529
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

specified range. For releases from master treat the message as an
error. For other branches treat the message as a warning.

commit_message:
report warnings when the supported versions of dependencies change

Compute the dependency set for the python code being released and
report when the old minimum version no longer falls within the
specified range. For releases from master treat the message as an
error. For other branches treat the message as a warning.

Update clone_repo() to return the location where the clone was written
as a convenience to the caller.

Extract the logic for determining if a version is using
pre-versioning (alpha, beta, etc.) so it can be reused.

Change-Id: I22a2f6df7f3502e4fcbf2d61ef5fee849ab15529
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Release keystoneauth 3.3.0

The main driver for this is Id9bd19cca68206fc64d23b0eaa95aa3e5b01b676,
which is needed for the cinder pieces of nova blueprint
use-ksa-adapter-for-endpoints.

This is 3.3.0 rather than 3.2.1 due to the intervening requirements
bumps.

Change-Id: I8829df84f173fed3b0b1e0579883533244dae135

commit_message:
Add pike as release using old deps repo.

When submitting
Id53b609ff6f31e1da96598c180151239be287242
it was forgotten to take pike release
into account as the new url change
is happening for queens and next releases.

Change-Id: I7e7a1ea7e1bda8e43ab8fdac8cd52ee2677e329b

subject: SUSE: Apply workaround for mariadb-10.2
messages: [{'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2017-11-29 10:02:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2017-11-29 11:56:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 538, 'date': '2017-11-29 13:30:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 6816, 'date': '2017-11-29 16:26:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2017-11-29 19:47:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:\n\nrecheck'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-29 10:02:13.000000000', 'message': 'SUSE: Apply workaround for mariadb-10.2

The openSUSE repository bumped the mariadb package to 10.2. However,
there is an upstream bug that prevents nodes from joining the cluster.
The way to workaround it is to export WSREP_SST_OPT_PORT=4444 in the
systemd service file. Moreover, we pull the mariadb-galera subpackage
which contains some necessary tools for galera clusters. Finally,
we drop the default configuration files which are being installed by
the packages because they conflict with the ones installed by this role.

[hwoarang: This also applies the linter fixes from
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/523080/ in order to make the
gates happy]

Depends-On: Ia4856f36b2d106d987e3c774f31493e25a23d4b5
Link: https://jira.mariadb.org/browse/MDEV-14256
Change-Id: I97cf1585b2fed08f53f62a547547e422bc34fa53
(cherry picked from commit 546c402b5cab0fce45eaaec8f3661ef178abb83d)
'}]
commit_message:
SUSE: Apply workaround for mariadb-10.2

The openSUSE repository bumped the mariadb package to 10.2. However,
there is an upstream bug that prevents nodes from joining the cluster.
The way to workaround it is to export WSREP_SST_OPT_PORT=4444 in the
systemd service file. Moreover, we pull the mariadb-galera subpackage
which contains some necessary tools for galera clusters. Finally,
we drop the default configuration files which are being installed by
the packages because they conflict with the ones installed by this role.

[hwoarang: This also applies the linter fixes from
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/523080/ in order to make the
gates happy]

Depends-On: Ia4856f36b2d106d987e3c774f31493e25a23d4b5
Link: https://jira.mariadb.org/browse/MDEV-14256
Change-Id: I97cf1585b2fed08f53f62a547547e422bc34fa53
(cherry picked from commit 546c402b5cab0fce45eaaec8f3661ef178abb83d)

commit_message:
zuul: run TripleO jobs with new zuulv3 layout

Configure the layout to execute the scenario007 jobs.
Note that baremetal job will be run on stable/pike and container on
Queens and beyond.

A note has been added in comment explaining more details.

Change-Id: I61e9d316ad283076a735344635cbcb227ee0de09
Depends-On: I8f8f0ce918d83cc99792cb0554ec081d4c3bc20b
(cherry picked from commit 8b034ab0c3807f680688e492c00acba30cea60ab)

Add helper property to get the current user id

The data is available, but it's not the MOST straightforward thing to
find. We have helpers for project, add one for user.

commit_message:
Add ability to work in other auth contexts

Add methods and context managers to facilitate working in different
projects or different auth contexts, but sharing the Session and other
config information from the existing cloud. Sharing the Session allows
for version discovery cache to be shared, and keeps the user from
needing to do a bunch of work to get a cloud that's like the current one
but slightly different.

Change-Id: I9190ee725cad00db4e0b6ed8321e3021a703a2e4

commit_message:
Sort image update results before comparing

The patch created by jsonpatch is not in a consistent order. Sort the
dicts before comparing them.

Change-Id: Ieedd26d759b98cecca91f1efb9d021da46304891

[{'created': '2017-11-22 14:21:41.000000000', 'message': "Make close on cryptsetup volumes idempotent

When recovering from the failure of a compute host, Nova can call
close on an encryptor whose state Nova can't be certain of, but which
hasn't been created. This change makes the close operation idempotent,
which allows recovery to be more robust.

Related-bug: #1724573
Change-Id: I9f52f89b8466d03699cfd5c0e32c672c934cd6fb
"}]
commit_message:
Make close on cryptsetup volumes idempotent

When recovering from the failure of a compute host, Nova can call
close on an encryptor whose state Nova can't be certain of, but which
hasn't been created. This change makes the close operation idempotent,
which allows recovery to be more robust.

Related-bug: #1724573
Change-Id: I9f52f89b8466d03699cfd5c0e32c672c934cd6fb

[{'created': '2017-05-26 04:19:15.000000000', 'message': '[WIP]: Add rpc callback for logging extension

detail log information for each log object such as which
ports, which sg rules are attached to log object.

  get_sg_log_info_for_port and get_sg_log_info_for_log_resources.

Change-Id: I7d50356dd1da49af6faaaa8969b6ae9041f81063
Partially-implements: blueprint security-group-logging
Related-Bug: #1468366
'}]
commit_message:
[log]: Add driver api and rpc stuff for logging

This patch adds driver api and rpc stuff for logging extension as
below:
- Provides create, update and delete log api for log drivers
- Reserves a rpc notification api for log drivers if a log driver
requires rpc.
- Reserves a rpc listener for listening callback from log drivers.
- Also provides db_api: get_logs_bound_port, get_logs_bound_sg and
  get_sg_log_info_for_port and get_sg_log_info_for_log_resources.

Change-Id: I7d50356dd1da49af6faaaa8969b6ae9041f81063
Partially-implements: blueprint security-group-logging
Related-Bug: #1468366

commit_message:
Add policy roadmap for security

Add a roadmap that describes the long term policy vision that
eliminates the security issues we have today.

Co-Authored-By: Matthew Edmonds <edmondsw@us.ibm.com>
Co-Authored-By: Adam Young <ayoung@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I0b639640764aedbeb17765a337ac640418138533

commit_message:
Use infra specific beaker rspec template

The infra required projects needs and the not infra required projects
needs differ so we need to use different templates for infra than for
everything else. Use those infra specific templates.

Change-Id: If1dd8f4456c598d174cc67393534c610867e421f
Depends-On: Icf7ec289d51a3e7b7374f8aef5a94d18ec12bc94

commit_message:
Fix xio driver bug: cloned with src vol size

It's possible to create a volume from a source volume with
a larger size. However, xio driver does not extend
the volume when clone has finished. This patch fixes it.

The volume has not been created with OVO and a seperate patch
will be created to switch the dictionary to OVO implementation
regarding volume / snapshot to follow up Gorka's comments.

Co-Authored-By: Xinli Guan <xinli@us.ibm.com>

Change-Id: Icd626ff894e052f557f3da9439b217ed4924014e
Closes-Bug: #1554764

commit_message:
Make infra specific beaker rspec template

Turns out the puppet openstack modules do run the legacy xenial beaker
rspec job. I had thought they were completely off of the legacy job
config but was wrong. This means we need new templates for infra that
add in the infra repos and need to restore the existing templates that
don't add in the infra repos for the puppet openstack modules.

Change-Id: Icf7ec289d51a3e7b7374f8aef5a94d18ec12bc94

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-03 06:54:20.000000000', 'message': 'libvirt: do unicode conversion for error messages.

The error messages from libvirt are LANG aware.
If we deploy nova and libvirt on an non-English language
OS, we may got non-ASCII from libvirt.

We should use exception_to_unicode to cover this senario.

Change-Id: I485dc1c92aad8347b505d6ece9e6191da931ec72
Signed-off-by: Chen Hanxiao <chenhx@certusnet.com.cn>
'}]
commit_message:
libvirt: do unicode conversion for error messages.

The error messages from libvirt are LANG aware.
If we deploy nova and libvirt on an non-English language
OS, we may got non-ASCII from libvirt.

We should use exception_to_unicode to cover this senario.

Change-Id: I485dc1c92aad8347b505d6ece9e6191da931ec72
Signed-off-by: Chen Hanxiao <chenhx@certusnet.com.cn>

commit_message:
Remove deprecated TrustedFilter

The TrustedFilter and the related trusted_computing config options
were deprecated in Pike:

  If6e53feeb97e6050c1eb7962110ed89504c952fc

Co-Authored-By: Matt Riedemann <mriedem.os@gmail.com>

Change-Id: I0a7ab3a4fb2cfad567a8644bed4de574393ee11a

(2 comments)

oslo.config provides the option to make this a reality while defaulting to immutable (ie you can select certain options and mark them as mutable), so I think it's natural to allow people to do this if they want.

My suggestion would be to call that out specifically in the spec.  Also, I would try to avoid anything really specific in here in terms of what you want to make mutable and instead just point out that "there's some benefit to allowing dynamic reconfig of some options for drivers" etc.  

Questions I'd have:
1. how to determine what should/shouldn't be allowed to be changed
2. should the spec focus on just the non-driver things (default type, etc)
3. should we leave driver things to drivers and just mention that they can choose to use this if they want etc?

Hope that makes sense, thanks for the detailed spec, would just like to see some references to the oslo.config enhancments and the recent change to services that landed and makes mutable possible.'}, {'account_id': 7198, 'date': '2017-06-28 18:51:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

Ok, I am going to try and capture the variety of discussion that has happened.

Since we have started this spec the field has changed somewhat.  We now know that doing a SIGHUP should get us the desired functionality with Oslo so we don't need to re-invent the wheel here.  We also now know that it is possible to have mutable and not mutable config options:  https://review.openstack.org/#/c/464028/2

With further investigation, Walt had pointed out the fact that allowing dynamic reconfiguration of many configuration options is dangerous.  Not something we had previously considered.

So, in discussion on the channel I don't think we need to scrap this spec but that we need to refocus a bit.  I think we are moving to something like the following:

1) Fix Cinder so that it properly handles a SIGHUP as that is clearly broken right now.
2) Pick a few safe configuration options to make mutable as a PoC.
3) Merge that as a starting point.
4) Slowly expand the list of mutable config options as appropriate.
5) Document this effort.
6) Leave it up to driver maintainers as to whether they want to make options mutable.

Just trying to break this down into bite size pieces.  I don't think we are at the point where we think this effort is pointless.
I think we just need to refocus a bit here to help guide the way
forward."}, {'account_id': 5997, 'date': '2017-06-28 21:52:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(6 comments)

Thanks for bringing this spec up in the meeting today.   I took some more time looking at this as well as the way drivers are created and used today with respect to their config objects.   I have provided some feedback in the spec review that will hopefully get addressed before this merges. 

We don't have to solve every single problem in the world, but I think this spec needs to discuss how drivers will get their new config objects and talk about some of the dangers of said updates to the drivers.   For the problems the spec can't solve, it needs to call them out and let everyone know what the limitations are.

For example, some drivers use separate threads that do work and return from the entry point (call from the volume manager).   Sending a new config object to that driver, while the thread is running in the background may be disastrous to that driver and it's backend.  We don't have to fix those driver's issues, but we do need to call this out and potentially prohibit those drivers from getting a new config object until their maintainer can test it.   


Looking at the backup service, the config settings act just like they do in volume drivers.  The backup service driver gets it's configuration settings at instantiation time. 

I would also like to see some operator based use cases of why this is even something we want to do.   I provided one simple one that might be useful....to one driver, but I'm not convinced just yet that this is useful."}, {'account_id': 23083, 'date': '2017-07-04 16:19:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

Agree with hemna, and several thoughts after testing this feature in my environment, hope it can help.
1. Oslo [1] and cinder [2] both already support mutable config options, and that **do
work** with daemon service. So we can utilize those existing features and focus on the business specific logic and changes.
2. For our framework's config options, maybe we can start to find out those safe  options, mark them mutable=True and then make them mutable safe with the guidence of oslo.config [3] and also document this for our driver.
3. For driver part, maybe we can add new interface which will be invoked when service.reset is called. So the driver could have a change to go check their options and error out.
4. Can we add a new API to trigger the SIGHUP signal for different services at one time (sounds like unreasonable), it's useful when multiple services are deployed on different sites.
5. Oslo is talking about enable database (etcd) as oslo_config's backend. Maybe we can make the configuration reload process more flexible for administrator by enabling this [4]


[1]: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/251471/
[2]: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/464028/
[3]: https://docs.openstack.org/oslo.config/latest/reference/mutable.html#id2
[4]: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/454897/"}, {'account_id': 16708, 'date': '2017-07-07 19:15:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(7 comments)'}, {'account_id': 16708, 'date': '2017-07-07 19:15:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-07-07 19:19:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified-1

commit_message:
Update Dynamic Reconfig Spec

This patch cleans up formatting issues with the spec. It adds
new information about options that should not be modified and the
slightly modified direction of the spec.

Change-Id: I417f69895437eaae42ade8927518dfc36eb01646

[{'created': '2017-11-17 06:57:52.000000000', 'message': "Stage call fails with TypeError

If store_backend denies writing to store then glance_store will raise
'StorageWriteDenied' error. After catching this exception at glance
side, unstage call fails with TypeError as it requires 3 arguments
and only two were provided.

Passed 'staging_store' argument to _unstage call for correcting the
same.

Change-Id: I6d3d1b304e84fbfc1d653b3640ed92082f5b11cd
Closes-Bug: #1732835
"}, {'created': '2017-11-29 14:34:08.000000000', 'message': "Fix unstage after staging store denies write

If store_backend denies writing to store then glance_store will raise
'StorageWriteDenied' error. After catching this exception at glance
side, unstage call fails with TypeError as it requires 3 arguments
and only two were provided.

Passed 'staging_store' argument to _unstage call for correcting the

Change-Id: I6d3d1b304e84fbfc1d653b3640ed92082f5b11cd

commit_message:
Fix unstage after staging store denies write

If store_backend denies writing to store then glance_store will raise
'StorageWriteDenied' error. After catching this exception at glance
side, unstage call fails with TypeError as it requires 3 arguments
and only two were provided.

Passed 'staging_store' argument to _unstage call for correcting the
same.

Change-Id: I6d3d1b304e84fbfc1d653b3640ed92082f5b11cd
Closes-Bug: #1732835

(2 comments)

The -1 is for the nits at 271 which might cause some confusion.

A 0 for the following comments/queries:

Is root_provider_uuid an optimization to avoid traversing parent until parent is null? Or does it do "more" than that? If it is a sql^wrdbms-driven optimization does it need to be present in the object model/fields or can we hide it behind an object method? The properties desired seem to be "am I a root?" (answered by parent being null or uuid = root_uuid) and "what is my root?" (answered either by traversing parents or looking at root_uuid).

Also, with regard to timofey's comment about needing backward compatibility. He's right: if we're passing resource provider objects over the wire and some can be newer versions that the receiver then we need to allow them to be bounced and transformed to the old version, right?

However, are there any scenarios now, and do we want any in the future, where a resource provider traverses RPC? At the moment they are internal to the placement service and the placement service is explicitly non-RPC. nova.objects are used as a convenient facade and encapsulator. Maybe we can be less concerned (at least for now) about versioning the objects in the placement service?'}, {'account_id': 1063, 'date': '2016-10-11 16:33:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

I'm still not clear on why we need this. Does it matter that (using the example in the commit msg) VF1 is provided by SR-IOV PF? To ask another way, the only actual inventory are the VFs; why is stating that they are provided by the compute host insufficient? Unless there is a solid reason why we need to know the details of how those VFs are created, this looks like a lot of unnecessary complication."}, {'account_id': 1063, 'date': '2016-10-11 16:36:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Also - why would this be limited to one layer of nesting? Not that I have any examples in mind, but couldn't a compute node have a physical device that has several components, each of which can create many virtual components? It seems that there is no logical bottom to this rabbit hole."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2016-10-11 17:03:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

@edleafe: Good questions, glad you're asking them. On the matter of why this nesting/hierarchy of providers is necessary, I'll give you an answer using the canonical example of SRIOV physical functions.

Let's say a compute host has 2 SRIOV-enabled NICs, each with 8 VFs on them. One of the physical NICs is associated with network A. The other is associated with network B. If we only had a single provider of resources of type SRIOV_NET_VF and used the compute host as the resource provider, there would be no way to distinguish the virtual functions associated with network A from the virtual functions associated with network B.

The entity against which qualitative traits are associated is the resource provider, not the resource itself -- since the resource itself is a simple integer quantity of a type of consumable thing.

When doing resource accounting for certain types of resource classes such as SRIOV_NET_VF, it's important to be able to request quantities of VFs from a provider that has a specified set of qualitative traits.

Further examples of the need for nested resource providers can be found in how to account for quantitative resources in NUMA nodes. Each NUMA node has a finite amount of physical to virtual CPUs that can be mapped to a requested NUMA topology. If all VCPU resources were only set in the inventory of the compute host resource provider, there would be no way for VCPU usage to be tracked per NUMA node. Tracking consumption of VCPU per NUMA node is something that is a critical feature for various high-performance virtual network functions, and without the nested resource provider structure, there would be no way to differentiate between NUMA node inventories/usage on a compute host.

Regarding the question about levels of nesting, I've left that entirely open. Right now, the only examples I see use a single parent-child relationship, but there's nothing about this new DB schema and object attributes that prevent deeper levels of nesting if needed in the future.

Best,

-jay"}, {'account_id': 13692, 'date': '2016-10-11 18:10:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Is it possible for creating inventory and allocations for any resource providers? I have concerns, that while it is alright for any leaf providers, than allocating anything on root provider might be dangerous. Especially when child provider have something already allocated.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-10-11 22:37:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Verified-1

Merge Failed.

This change or one of its cross-repo dependencies was unable to be automatically merged with the current state of its repository. Please rebase the change and upload a new patchset.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2016-10-12 17:15:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(6 comments)'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2016-10-12 17:16:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

@gryf_: yes, inventory and allocations may absolutely be set against any resource provider. Can you explain in a little more detail a specific scenario where you worry about a parent and a child both having inventory records?

Thanks!

-jay'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2016-10-12 17:23:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2016-10-12 18:08:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2016-10-12 18:20:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Make a lot more sense now, thanks.

I'm still wondering from my earlier comments:

Is root_provider_uuid an optimization to avoid traversing parent until parent is null? Or does it do "more" than that? If it is a sql^wrdbms-driven optimization does it need to be present in the object model/fields or can we hide it behind an object method? The properties desired seem to be "am I a root?" (answered by parent being null or uuid = root_uuid) and "what is my root?" (answered either by traversing parents or looking at root_uuid).'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2016-10-12 18:51:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

@cdent: The root_provider_uuid provides an optimized search path for the most common query of the nested resource provider trees: get me all resource providers that are "on this compute host". With the ability to have >1 level of nesting, we would need to perform a recursive SQL query to get all the resource providers on a compute host instead of a single SQL query:

 SELECT * FROM resource_providers
 WHERE root_provider_uuid = $COMPUTE_NODE_UUID;

Best,

-jay'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-10-12 19:12:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Verified-1

@cdent: I actually did add a unit test for the obj_make_compatible() stuff:

    def test_custom_resource_raises(self):
        """Ensure that if we send an inventory object to a backversioned 1.0
        receiver, that we raise ValueError if the inventory record contains a
        custom (non-standardized) resource class.
        """
        values = {
            'name': 'rp1',
            'uuid': _RESOURCE_PROVIDER_UUID,
            'root_provider_uuid': _RESOURCE_PROVIDER_UUID,
            'parent_provider_uuid': None
        }
        rp = objects.ResourceProvider(context=self.context, **values)
        p = rp.obj_to_primitive(target_version='1.1')
        self.assertNotIn('root_provider_uuid', p)
        self.assertNotIn('parent_provider_uuid', p)

The problem is I copy/pasted it from the custom resource classes patch and forgot to change the name of the dang unit test ;)

I'll fix up shortly.

@jaypipes - we have forced ironic to create a separate resource class for each minor variation in configuration that it offers. Why can't we have separate classes for the two network configurations for VFs? You stated that it was a bad thing for SRIOV, so why is it OK for ironic?

We also discussed this sort of nesting in Austin, but in the context of FPGAs. Besides not wanting to get into the FPGA management business, we decided that we would only treat the resulting programmed slots as resources, and not the FPGA itself. Now this proposal seems to back up from that. With this, there is no reason that the FPGA can't be a child RP, and the programs be the inventory.

Your comments in IRC today about also having to manage PFs and VFs also seem to complicate this. In the nested rp model, these can be either inventory or a RP, depending on how it is consumed, and will have to be able to switch back-and-forth between the two. That just seems like a workaround to a mismatched design.

If you really want, I could re-write some of my earlier proposals that never made it very far to see if they might meet the design needs better. But I'm sure that sunk costs will win in the end."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2016-10-14 19:44:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

@edleafe: Ironic nodes have a "node_class" attribute that is going to be used to automatically populate the resource_class inventory. Please remember that Ironic nodes are also all resource providers because of the exact same constraint I mentioned earlier about only being able to associate qualitative information to the resource provider entity.

What earlier designs are you referring to, BTW? Are you referring to the design of using a document store instead of a relational database?'}, {'account_id': 1063, 'date': '2016-10-17 18:20:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

"document store"? When did I ever even talk about any such thing??

No, I meant some of my earlier proposals discussed in the beginning days of qualitative aspects of a request. And I've summarized this a bit better in a blog post: https://blog.leafe.com/virtual-bike-sheds/

We can discuss this further at the summit.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-10-18 02:37:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Verified-1

> @gryf_: yes, inventory and allocations may absolutely be set against any resource provider. Can you explain in a little more detail a specific scenario where you worry about a parent and a child both having inventory records?

@Jay, So the scenario I was thinking of is simply PCI case, where a PCI card can be consumed as a resource, or it might be virtualized with SR-IOV, where there can be several VFs available. If there are couple of available VFs allocated, than passing entire PCI card to another instance is not what I'd expect unless I get it wrong, and it's impossible for exposing PCI (meant for passthrough) with single-root I/O virtualization :)"}, {'account_id': 13692, 'date': '2016-11-03 21:07:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2016-11-07 18:06:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12: Patch Set 11 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-11-07 19:02:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Verified+1

revisions:
[{'created': '2016-09-27 01:07:59.000000000', 'message': 'placement - add nested resource providers

Adds initial support for storing the relationship between parent and
child resource providers. Nested resource providers are essential for
expressing certain types of resources -- in particular SR-IOV physical
functions and certain SR-IOV fully-programmable gate arrays. The
resources that these providers expose are of resource class SRIOV_NET_VF
and we will need a way of indicating that the physical function
providing these virtual function resources is tagged with certain
attributes (could be vendor_id, product_id or something like physnet
tagging representing the physical network the PF is attached to).

The compute host is a resource provider which has an SR-IOV-enabled
physical function (NIC) as a child resource provider. The physical
function has an inventory containing some total amount of SRIOV_NET_VF
resources. These SRIOV_NET_VF resources are allocated to zero or more
consumers (instances) on the compute host.

                    compute host (parent resource provider)
                         |
                         |
                      SR-IOV PF  (child resource provider)
                         :
                        / \
                       /   \
                    VF1    VF2   (inventory of child provider)

The resource provider model gets two new fields:

 - root_provider_uuid: The "top" or "root" of the tree of nested
   providers
 - parent_provider_uuid: The immediate parent of the provider, or None
   if the provider is a root provider.

The root_provider_uuid field is non-nullable and this code includes an
online data migration to automatically populate the root_provider_uuid
field with the value of the resource_providers.uuid field for any
resource providers already in the DB.

We will be able to use both the root_provider_uuid and the
parent_provider_uuid in various queries from the resource tracker and
the scheduler to determine the compute hosts that have child providers
who can fulfill a particular requested amount of certain types of
resources like an SRIOV_NET_VF.

Logic in this patch ensures that no resource provider can be deleted if
any of its children have any allocations active on them. We also check
to ensure that when created or updated, a resource provider's root and
parent provider UUID actually points to an existing provider.

Change-Id: I2d8df57f77a03cde898d9ec792c5d59b75f61204
blueprint: nested-resource-providers

Adds initial support for storing the relationship between parent and
child resource providers. Nested resource providers are essential for
expressing certain types of resources -- in particular SR-IOV physical
functions and certain SR-IOV fully-programmable gate arrays. The
resources that these providers expose are of resource class SRIOV_NET_VF
and we will need a way of indicating that the physical function
providing these virtual function resources is tagged with certain
attributes (could be vendor_id, product_id or something like physnet
tagging representing the physical network the PF is attached to).

The compute host is a resource provider which has an SR-IOV-enabled
physical function (NIC) as a child resource provider. The physical
function has an inventory containing some total amount of SRIOV_NET_VF
resources. These SRIOV_NET_VF resources are allocated to zero or more
consumers (instances) on the compute host.

                    compute host (parent resource provider)
                         |
                         |
                      SR-IOV PF  (child resource provider)
                         :
                        / \
                       /   \
                    VF1    VF2   (inventory of child provider)

The resource provider model gets two new fields:

 - root_provider_uuid: The "top" or "root" of the tree of nested
   providers
 - parent_provider_uuid: The immediate parent of the provider, or None
   if the provider is a root provider.

The root_provider_uuid field is non-nullable and this code includes an
online data migration to automatically populate the root_provider_uuid
field with the value of the resource_providers.uuid field for any
resource providers already in the DB.

We will be able to use both the root_provider_uuid and the
parent_provider_uuid in various queries from the resource tracker and
the scheduler to determine the compute hosts that have child providers
who can fulfill a particular requested amount of certain types of
resources like an SRIOV_NET_VF.

Logic in this patch ensures that no resource provider can be deleted if
any of its children have any allocations active on them. We also check
to ensure that when created or updated, a resource provider's root and
parent provider UUID actually points to an existing provider. Finally,
if an provider has its parent provider UUID set to a non-None value, we
automatically set that provider's root provider UUID to the root of the
parent provider.

Change-Id: I2d8df57f77a03cde898d9ec792c5d59b75f61204

'}, {'created': '2016-10-12 17:23:48.000000000', 'message': 'placement: add nested resource providers

Adds initial support for storing the relationship between parent and
child resource providers. Nested resource providers are essential for
expressing certain types of resources -- in particular SR-IOV physical
functions and certain SR-IOV fully-programmable gate arrays. The
resources that these providers expose are of resource class SRIOV_NET_VF
and we will need a way of indicating that the physical function
providing these virtual function resources is tagged with certain
attributes (could be vendor_id, product_id or something like physnet
tagging representing the physical network the PF is attached to).

The compute host is a resource provider which has an SR-IOV-enabled
physical function (NIC) as a child resource provider. The physical
function has an inventory containing some total amount of SRIOV_NET_VF
resources. These SRIOV_NET_VF resources are allocated to zero or more
consumers (instances) on the compute host.

                    compute host (parent resource provider)
                         |
                         |
                      SR-IOV PF  (child resource provider)
                         :
                        / \
                       /   \
                    VF1    VF2   (inventory of child provider)

The resource provider model gets two new fields:

 - root_provider_uuid: The "top" or "root" of the tree of nested
   providers
 - parent_provider_uuid: The immediate parent of the provider, or None
   if the provider is a root provider.

The root_provider_uuid field is non-nullable and this code includes an
online data migration to automatically populate the root_provider_uuid
field with the value of the resource_providers.uuid field for any
resource providers already in the DB.

We will be able to use both the root_provider_uuid and the
parent_provider_uuid in various queries from the resource tracker and
the scheduler to determine the compute hosts that have child providers
who can fulfill a particular requested amount of certain types of
resources like an SRIOV_NET_VF.

Logic in this patch ensures that no resource provider can be deleted if
any of its children have any allocations active on them. We also check
to ensure that when created or updated, a resource provider's root and
parent provider UUID actually points to an existing provider. Finally,
if an provider has its parent provider UUID set to a non-None value, we
automatically set that provider's root provider UUID to the root of the
parent provider.

It's important to point out that qualitative trait information is only
associated with a resource provider entity, not the resources that
resource provider has in its inventory. This is the reason why nested
resource providers are necessary. In the case of things like NUMA nodes
or SRIOV physical functions, if a compute host had multiple SRIOV
physical functions, each associated with a different network trait,
there would be no way to differentiate between the SRIOV_NET_VF
resources that those multiple SRIOV physical functions provided if the
containing compute host had a single inventory item containing the total
number of VFs exposed by both PFs.

Change-Id: I2d8df57f77a03cde898d9ec792c5d59b75f61204
blueprint: nested-resource-providers

'}, {'created': '2016-10-12 19:49:22.000000000', 'message': 'placement: add nested resource providers

Adds initial support for storing the relationship between parent and
child resource providers. Nested resource providers are essential for
expressing certain types of resources -- in particular SR-IOV physical
functions and certain SR-IOV fully-programmable gate arrays. The
resources that these providers expose are of resource class SRIOV_NET_VF
and we will need a way of indicating that the physical function
providing these virtual function resources is tagged with certain
attributes (could be vendor_id, product_id or something like physnet
tagging representing the physical network the PF is attached to).

The compute host is a resource provider which has an SR-IOV-enabled
physical function (NIC) as a child resource provider. The physical
function has an inventory containing some total amount of SRIOV_NET_VF
resources. These SRIOV_NET_VF resources are allocated to zero or more
consumers (instances) on the compute host.

                    compute host (parent resource provider)
                         |
                         |
                      SR-IOV PF  (child resource provider)
                         :
                        / \
                       /   \
                    VF1    VF2   (inventory of child provider)

The resource provider model gets two new fields:

 - root_provider_uuid: The "top" or "root" of the tree of nested
   providers
 - parent_provider_uuid: The immediate parent of the provider, or None
   if the provider is a root provider.

The root_provider_uuid field is non-nullable and this code includes an
online data migration to automatically populate the root_provider_uuid
field with the value of the resource_providers.uuid field for any
resource providers already in the DB.

We will be able to use both the root_provider_uuid and the
parent_provider_uuid in various queries from the resource tracker and
the scheduler to determine the compute hosts that have child providers
who can fulfill a particular requested amount of certain types of
resources like an SRIOV_NET_VF.

Logic in this patch ensures that no resource provider can be deleted if
any of its children have any allocations active on them. We also check
to ensure that when created or updated, a resource provider's root and
parent provider UUID actually points to an existing provider. Finally,
if an provider has its parent provider UUID set to a non-None value, we
automatically set that provider's root provider UUID to the root of the
parent provider.

It's important to point out that qualitative trait information is only
associated with a resource provider entity, not the resources that
resource provider has in its inventory. This is the reason why nested
resource providers are necessary. In the case of things like NUMA nodes
or SRIOV physical functions, if a compute host had multiple SRIOV
physical functions, each associated with a different network trait,
there would be no way to differentiate between the SRIOV_NET_VF
resources that those multiple SRIOV physical functions provided if the
containing compute host had a single inventory item containing the total
number of VFs exposed by both PFs.

Change-Id: I2d8df57f77a03cde898d9ec792c5d59b75f61204
blueprint: nested-resource-providers

Co-Authored-By: Moshe Levi <moshele@mellanox.com>
'}, {'created': '2016-11-21 16:12:24.000000000', 'message': 'placement: add nested resource providers

Adds initial support for storing the relationship between parent and
child resource providers. Nested resource providers are essential for
expressing certain types of resources -- in particular SR-IOV physical
functions and certain SR-IOV fully-programmable gate arrays. The
resources that these providers expose are of resource class SRIOV_NET_VF
and we will need a way of indicating that the physical function
providing these virtual function resources is tagged with certain
attributes (could be vendor_id, product_id or something like physnet
tagging representing the physical network the PF is attached to).

The compute host is a resource provider which has an SR-IOV-enabled
physical function (NIC) as a child resource provider. The physical
function has an inventory containing some total amount of SRIOV_NET_VF
resources. These SRIOV_NET_VF resources are allocated to zero or more
consumers (instances) on the compute host.

                    compute host (parent resource provider)
                         |
                         |
                      SR-IOV PF  (child resource provider)
                         :
                        / \
                       /   \
                    VF1    VF2   (inventory of child provider)

The resource provider model gets two new fields:

 - root_provider_uuid: The "top" or "root" of the tree of nested
   providers
 - parent_provider_uuid: The immediate parent of the provider, or None
   if the provider is a root provider.

The root_provider_uuid field is non-nullable and this code includes an
online data migration to automatically populate the root_provider_uuid
field with the value of the resource_providers.uuid field for any
resource providers already in the DB.

The root_provider_uuid field is intended to be an internal
implementation detail of the resource providers data model. Its value is
populated automatically when a provider is created. If the parent
provider UUID is set, then the root_provider_uuid is set to the
root_provider_uuid value of the parent. If parent is unset,
root_provider_uuid is set to the uuid attribute value of the provider
being created.

The root_provider_uuid field allows us to do extremely quick lookups of
an entire tree of providers without needing to perform any recursive
database queries.

Logic in this patch ensures that no resource provider can be deleted if
any of its children have any allocations active on them. We also check
to ensure that when created or updated, a resource provider's parent
provider UUID actually points to an existing provider.

It's important to point out that qualitative trait information is only
associated with a resource provider entity, not the resources that
resource provider has in its inventory. This is the reason why nested
resource providers are necessary. In the case of things like NUMA nodes
or SRIOV physical functions, if a compute host had multiple SRIOV
physical functions, each associated with a different network trait,
there would be no way to differentiate between the SRIOV_NET_VF
resources that those multiple SRIOV physical functions provided if the
containing compute host had a single inventory item containing the total
number of VFs exposed by both PFs.

Change-Id: I2d8df57f77a03cde898d9ec792c5d59b75f61204
blueprint: nested-resource-providers
Co-Authored-By: Moshe Levi <moshele@mellanox.com>

implementation detail of the resource providers data model. Its value is
populated automatically when a provider is created. If the parent
provider UUID is set, then the root_provider_uuid is set to the
root_provider_uuid value of the parent. If parent is unset,
root_provider_uuid is set to the value of the uuid attribute of the
provider being created.

The root_provider_uuid field allows us to do extremely quick lookups of
an entire tree of providers without needing to perform any recursive
database queries.

Logic in this patch ensures that no resource provider can be deleted if
any of its children have any allocations active on them. We also check
to ensure that when created or updated, a resource provider's parent
provider UUID actually points to an existing provider.

It's important to point out that qualitative trait information is only
associated with a resource provider entity, not the resources that
resource provider has in its inventory. This is the reason why nested
resource providers are necessary. In the case of things like NUMA nodes
or SRIOV physical functions, if a compute host had multiple SRIOV
physical functions, each associated with a different network trait,
there would be no way to differentiate between the SRIOV_NET_VF
resources that those multiple SRIOV physical functions provided if the
containing compute host had a single inventory item containing the total
number of VFs exposed by both PFs.

Change-Id: I2d8df57f77a03cde898d9ec792c5d59b75f61204
blueprint: nested-resource-providers
Co-Authored-By: Moshe Levi <moshele@mellanox.com>
'}, {'created': '2017-01-11 20:56:33.000000000', 'message': 'placement: add nested resource providers

Adds initial support for storing the relationship between parent and
child resource providers. Nested resource providers are essential for
expressing certain types of resources -- in particular SR-IOV physical
functions and certain SR-IOV fully-programmable gate arrays. The
resources that these providers expose are of resource class SRIOV_NET_VF
and we will need a way of indicating that the physical function
providing these virtual function resources is tagged with certain
attributes (could be vendor_id, product_id or something like physnet
tagging representing the physical network the PF is attached to).

The compute host is a resource provider which has an SR-IOV-enabled
physical function (NIC) as a child resource provider. The physical
function has an inventory containing some total amount of SRIOV_NET_VF
resources. These SRIOV_NET_VF resources are allocated to zero or more
consumers (instances) on the compute host.

                    compute host (parent resource provider)
                         |
                         |
                      SR-IOV PF  (child resource provider)
                         :
                        / \
                       /   \
                    VF1    VF2   (inventory of child provider)

The resource provider model gets two new fields:

 - root_provider_uuid: The "top" or "root" of the tree of nested
   providers
 - parent_provider_uuid: The immediate parent of the provider, or None
   if the provider is a root provider.

The root_provider_uuid field is non-nullable and this code includes an
online data migration to automatically populate the root_provider_uuid
field with the value of the resource_providers.uuid field for any

SRIOV_NET_VF and we will need a way of indicating that the physical
function providing these virtual function resources is tagged with
certain attributes (could be vendor_id, product_id or something like
physnet tagging representing the physical network the PF is attached
to).

The compute host is a resource provider which has an SR-IOV-enabled
physical function (NIC) as a child resource provider. The physical
function has an inventory containing some total amount of SRIOV_NET_VF
resources. These SRIOV_NET_VF resources are allocated to zero or more
consumers (instances) on the compute host.

                    compute host (parent resource provider)
                         |
                         |
                      SR-IOV PF  (child resource provider)
                         :
                        / \
                       /   \
                    VF1    VF2   (inventory of child provider)

The resource provider model gets two new fields:

 - root_provider_uuid: The "top" or "root" of the tree of nested
   providers
 - parent_provider_uuid: The immediate parent of the provider, or None
   if the provider is a root provider.

The root_provider_uuid field is non-nullable and this code includes an
online data migration to automatically populate the root_provider_uuid
field with the value of the resource_providers.uuid field for any
resource providers already in the DB.

The root_provider_uuid field is intended to be an internal
implementation detail of the resource providers data model. Its value
is populated automatically when a provider is created. If the parent
provider UUID is set, then the root_provider_uuid is set to the
root_provider_uuid value of the parent. If parent is unset,
root_provider_uuid is set to the value of the uuid attribute of the
provider being created.

The root_provider_uuid field allows us to do extremely quick lookups of
an entire tree of providers without needing to perform any recursive
database queries.

Logic in this patch ensures that no resource provider can be deleted if
any of its children have any allocations active on them. We also check
to ensure that when created or updated, a resource provider's parent
provider UUID actually points to an existing provider.

It's important to point out that qualitative trait information is only
associated with a resource provider entity, not the resources that
resource provider has in its inventory. This is the reason why nested
resource providers are necessary. In the case of things like NUMA nodes
or SRIOV physical functions, if a compute host had multiple SRIOV
physical functions, each associated with a different network trait,
there would be no way to differentiate between the SRIOV_NET_VF
resources that those multiple SRIOV physical functions provided if the
containing compute host had a single inventory item containing the
total number of VFs exposed by both PFs.

Change-Id: I2d8df57f77a03cde898d9ec792c5d59b75f61204
blueprint: nested-resource-providers
Co-Authored-By: Moshe Levi <moshele@mellanox.com>

'}, {'created': '2017-10-10 17:09:13.000000000', 'message': 'placement: add nested resource providers

Adds initial support for storing the relationship between parent and
child resource providers. Nested resource providers are essential for
expressing certain types of resources -- in particular SR-IOV physical
functions and certain SR-IOV fully-programmable gate arrays. The
resources that these providers expose are of resource class
SRIOV_NET_VF and we will need a way of indicating that the physical
function providing these virtual function resources is tagged with
certain traits (representing vendor_id, product_id or the physical
network the PF is attached to).

The compute host is a resource provider which has an SR-IOV-enabled
physical function (NIC) as a child resource provider. The physical
function has an inventory containing some total amount of SRIOV_NET_VF
resources. These SRIOV_NET_VF resources are allocated to zero or more
consumers (instances) on the compute host.

                    compute host (parent resource provider)
                         |
                         |
                      SR-IOV PF  (child resource provider)
                         :
                        / \
                       /   \
                    VF1    VF2   (inventory of child provider)

The resource provider model gets two new fields:

 - root_provider_uuid: The "top" or "root" of the tree of nested
   providers
 - parent_provider_uuid: The immediate parent of the provider, or None
   if the provider is a root provider.

The database schema adds two new columns to the resource_providers
table that contain the internal integer IDs that correspond to the
user-facing UUID values:

 - root_provider_id
 - parent_provider_id

The root_provider_uuid field is non-nullable in the ResourceProvider
object definition, and this code includes an online data migration to
automatically populate the root_provider_id field with the value of the
resource_providers.id field for any resource providers already in the
DB.

The root_provider_id field value is populated automatically when a
provider is created. If the parent provider UUID is set, then the
root_provider_id is set to the root_provider_id value of the parent. If
parent is unset, root_provider_id is set to the value of the id
attribute of the provider being created. The corresponding UUID values
for root and parent provider are fetched in the queries that retrieves
resource provider data using two self-referential joins.

The root_provider_id column allows us to do extremely quick lookups of
an entire tree of providers without needing to perform any recursive
database queries.

Logic in this patch ensures that no resource provider can be deleted if
any of its children have any allocations active on them. We also check
to ensure that when created or updated, a resource provider's parent
provider UUID actually points to an existing provider.

It's important to point out that qualitative trait information is only
associated with a resource provider entity, not the resources that
resource provider has in its inventory. This is the reason why nested
resource providers are necessary. In the case of things like NUMA nodes
or SRIOV physical functions, if a compute host had multiple SRIOV
physical functions, each associated with a different network trait,
there would be no way to differentiate between the SRIOV_NET_VF
resources that those multiple SRIOV physical functions provided if the
containing compute host had a single inventory item containing the
total number of VFs exposed by both PFs.

Change-Id: I2d8df57f77a03cde898d9ec792c5d59b75f61204
blueprint: nested-resource-providers
Co-Authored-By: Moshe Levi <moshele@mellanox.com>

root_provider_id is set to the root_provider_id value of the parent. If
parent is unset, root_provider_id is set to the value of the id
attribute of the provider being created. The corresponding UUID values
for root and parent provider are fetched in the queries that retrieves
resource provider data using two self-referential joins.

The root_provider_id column allows us to do extremely quick lookups of
an entire tree of providers without needing to perform any recursive
database queries.

Logic in this patch ensures that no resource provider can be deleted if
any of its children have any allocations active on them. We also check
to ensure that when created or updated, a resource provider's parent
provider UUID actually points to an existing provider.

It's important to point out that qualitative trait information is only
associated with a resource provider entity, not the resources that
resource provider has in its inventory. This is the reason why nested
resource providers are necessary. In the case of things like NUMA nodes
or SRIOV physical functions, if a compute host had multiple SRIOV
physical functions, each associated with a different network trait,
there would be no way to differentiate between the SRIOV_NET_VF
resources that those multiple SRIOV physical functions provided if the
containing compute host had a single inventory item containing the
total number of VFs exposed by both PFs.

Change-Id: I2d8df57f77a03cde898d9ec792c5d59b75f61204
blueprint: nested-resource-providers
Co-Authored-By: Moshe Levi <moshele@mellanox.com>

 - root_provider_id
 - parent_provider_id

The root_provider_uuid field is non-nullable in the ResourceProvider
object definition, and this code includes an online data migration to
automatically populate the root_provider_id field with the value of the
resource_providers.id field for any resource providers already in the
DB.

The root_provider_id field value is populated automatically when a
provider is created. If the parent provider UUID is set, then the
root_provider_id is set to the root_provider_id value of the parent. If
parent is unset, root_provider_id is set to the value of the id
attribute of the provider being created. The corresponding UUID values
for root and parent provider are fetched in the queries that retrieves
resource provider data using two self-referential joins.

The root_provider_id column allows us to do extremely quick lookups of
an entire tree of providers without needing to perform any recursive
database queries.

Logic in this patch ensures that no resource provider can be deleted if
any of its children have any allocations active on them. We also check
to ensure that when created or updated, a resource provider's parent
provider UUID actually points to an existing provider.

It's important to point out that qualitative trait information is only
associated with a resource provider entity, not the resources that
resource provider has in its inventory. This is the reason why nested
resource providers are necessary. In the case of things like NUMA nodes
or SRIOV physical functions, if a compute host had multiple SRIOV
physical functions, each associated with a different network trait,
there would be no way to differentiate between the SRIOV_NET_VF
resources that those multiple SRIOV physical functions provided if the
containing compute host had a single inventory item containing the
total number of VFs exposed by both PFs.

Change-Id: I2d8df57f77a03cde898d9ec792c5d59b75f61204
blueprint: nested-resource-providers
Co-Authored-By: Moshe Levi <moshele@mellanox.com>

commit_message:
placement: add nested resource providers

Adds initial support for storing the relationship between parent and
child resource providers. Nested resource providers are essential for
expressing certain types of resources -- in particular SR-IOV physical
functions and certain SR-IOV fully-programmable gate arrays. The
resources that these providers expose are of resource class
SRIOV_NET_VF and we will need a way of indicating that the physical
function providing these virtual function resources is tagged with
certain traits (representing vendor_id, product_id or the physical
network the PF is attached to).

The compute host is a resource provider which has an SR-IOV-enabled
physical function (NIC) as a child resource provider. The physical
function has an inventory containing some total amount of SRIOV_NET_VF
resources. These SRIOV_NET_VF resources are allocated to zero or more
consumers (instances) on the compute host.

                    compute host (parent resource provider)
                         |
                         |
                      SR-IOV PF  (child resource provider)
                         :
                        / \
                       /   \
                    VF1    VF2   (inventory of child provider)

The resource provider model gets two new fields:

 - root_provider_uuid: The "top" or "root" of the tree of nested
   providers
 - parent_provider_uuid: The immediate parent of the provider, or None
   if the provider is a root provider.

The database schema adds two new columns to the resource_providers
table that contain the internal integer IDs that correspond to the
user-facing UUID values:

 - root_provider_id
 - parent_provider_id

The root_provider_uuid field is non-nullable in the ResourceProvider
object definition, and this code includes an online data migration to
automatically populate the root_provider_id field with the value of the
resource_providers.id field for any resource providers already in the
DB.

The root_provider_id field value is populated automatically when a
provider is created. If the parent provider UUID is set, then the
root_provider_id is set to the root_provider_id value of the parent. If
parent is unset, root_provider_id is set to the value of the id
attribute of the provider being created. The corresponding UUID values
for root and parent provider are fetched in the queries that retrieves
resource provider data using two self-referential joins.

The root_provider_id column allows us to do extremely quick lookups of
an entire tree of providers without needing to perform any recursive
database queries.

Logic in this patch ensures that no resource provider can be deleted if
any of its children have any allocations active on them. We also check
to ensure that when created or updated, a resource provider's parent
provider UUID actually points to an existing provider.

It's important to point out that qualitative trait information is only
associated with a resource provider entity, not the resources that
resource provider has in its inventory. This is the reason why nested
resource providers are necessary. In the case of things like NUMA nodes
or SRIOV physical functions, if a compute host had multiple SRIOV
physical functions, each associated with a different network trait,
there would be no way to differentiate between the SRIOV_NET_VF
resources that those multiple SRIOV physical functions provided if the
containing compute host had a single inventory item containing the
total number of VFs exposed by both PFs.

Change-Id: I2d8df57f77a03cde898d9ec792c5d59b75f61204
blueprint: nested-resource-providers

commit_message:
sort when using groupby

groupby requires items to be sorted as it's clumping consecutive
items together. also, just use itemgetter instead of lambda

Change-Id: I1676fc60ebc2c9ff03ea00cc67061fdfb3b50868

commit_message:
Remove the instack-undercloud-puppet-lint job

This job got migrated and its playbook deleted. The definition of the
job was left in the repo, so now we have errors on instack-undercloud
check jobs.

Removing the definition to fix the issue.

Depends-On: I87141dc9a8ecbb563c4bd63ea47b179e33166905
Change-Id: Iabf5c6d5e5c7677f9f5c0523daedbef3526f5f53
Closes-Bug: #1734348

[{'created': '2017-11-28 19:45:19.000000000', 'message': "neutron: don't execute legacy in-tree tempest jobs for master

Those three legacy jobs - api plus two scenarios (both ovs/dvr and
linuxbridge) - rely on in-tree neutron tempest plugin that is going to
be removed with Ia21aad29d0bbf779583964db6f1665c9b3b83161. (The plugin
with all test cases was moved into a separate repo,
openstack/neutron-tempest-plugin.)

New jobs using the separate repo are already introduced for neutron
master branch, so at this point the legacy flavors are obsolete and
duplicate, and we should get rid of them to save resources as well as
move forward with tree cleanup.

There is ongoing work to move those jobs in-tree for stable branches:
I99ca4d4439782bd50a11f9d0f5ae6b0cfc4081c2. While we wait on the work to
finish, it makes sense to unblock work on tempest plugin by limiting the
legacy jobs to stable branches only.

Change-Id: Ie9516b203ca2efee41931972357900afd54ec71a
"}]
commit_message:
neutron: don't execute legacy in-tree tempest jobs for master

Those three legacy jobs - api plus two scenarios (both ovs/dvr and
linuxbridge) - rely on in-tree neutron tempest plugin that is going to
be removed with Ia21aad29d0bbf779583964db6f1665c9b3b83161. (The plugin
with all test cases was moved into a separate repo,
openstack/neutron-tempest-plugin.)

New jobs using the separate repo are already introduced for neutron
master branch, so at this point the legacy flavors are obsolete and
duplicate, and we should get rid of them to save resources as well as
move forward with tree cleanup.

There is ongoing work to move those jobs in-tree for stable branches:
I99ca4d4439782bd50a11f9d0f5ae6b0cfc4081c2. While we wait on the work to
finish, it makes sense to unblock work on tempest plugin by limiting the
legacy jobs to stable branches only.

Change-Id: Ie9516b203ca2efee41931972357900afd54ec71a

Change-Id: Iff50f517bb92fd19a620ab5b433cd2e52702cec0
"}]
commit_message:
Add required projects to legacy puppet rspec jobs

These rspec jobs install the entire set of modules declared by
system-config's modules env file. It also does so from source using
zuul-cloner so that we can do cross repo testing of our puppet modules.
Unfortunately these required projects were not listed on the jobs
resulting in errors from the zuul cloner shim when attempting to clone
these repos.

Add in all our puppet modules as required projects (as listed by the
zuul cloner shim) so that we fix this problem. We do this via a new job
that is infra specific so that we don't have to modify the required
projects list in multiple places to get the correct list.

Change-Id: Iff50f517bb92fd19a620ab5b433cd2e52702cec0

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-18 14:36:50.000000000', 'message': "Set agent debug config defaults to service default

A few of the neutron agents had a default of 'false' for the debug
flag. This interferes with the common practice of enabling debug through
a common configuration file (e.g. /etc/neutron.conf). This patch changes
the default to ::os_service_default allowing it to either use the
service default, values set in some common configuration or explicitly.

Change-Id: I7d7a1e4776861dc8d94a143edc0df76c3f963ef8
Closes-Bug: #1733071
"}]
commit_message:
Set agent debug config defaults to service default

A few of the neutron agents had a default of 'false' for the debug
flag. This interferes with the common practice of enabling debug through
a common configuration file (e.g. /etc/neutron.conf). This patch changes
the default to ::os_service_default allowing it to either use the
service default, values set in some common configuration or explicitly.

Change-Id: I7d7a1e4776861dc8d94a143edc0df76c3f963ef8
Closes-Bug: #1733071

commit_message:
Skip openstack-tox-py35 on requirements for newton

Back then we didn't pass the tests and it used to be
non-voting with Zuulv2, so remove it again so that
we can again land changes on stable/newton branch.

Change-Id: Id6bb6552b0b0e6f9c3584ac48e31505dda1ebc41

commit_message:
tripleo-ui: run javascript-tarball

Everytime we touch npm-shrinkwrap.json and package.json, we would like
to make sure that a tarball can be generated with npm tool.
For that, let's use build-javascript-tarball that exists in zuul-jobs
project.

Note: tripleo-ui seems to be the first project using this job.

Depends-On: Ida7130b482de0328a5517b8fe827efaff25b9461
Change-Id: I214b78eca3b2282e4c7f02974beac6dfb162043c

subject: Don't throw NotConnectedError in queue_txn
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 5756, 'name': 'Terry Wilson', 'email': 'twilson@redhat.com', 'username': 'otherwiseguy'}, {'_account_id': 8655, 'name': 'Jakub Libosvar', 'email': 'libosvar@redhat.com', 'username': 'jlibosva'}, {'_account_id': 8788, 'name': 'Miguel Angel Ajo', 'email': 'mangelajo@redhat.com', 'username': 'mangelajo'}, {'_account_id': 9656, 'name': 'Ihar Hrachyshka', 'email': 'ihrachys@redhat.com', 'username': 'ihrachys'}, {'_account_id': 20229, 'name': 'Omer Anson', 'email': 'omer.anson@toganetworks.com', 'username': 'oanson'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23804, 'name': 'Daniel Alvarez', 'email': 'dalvarez@redhat.com', 'username': 'dalvarez'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 5756, 'date': '2017-11-29 05:33:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 20229, 'date': '2017-11-29 06:40:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Thanks for the heads up. Running Dragonflow gate now to verify.'}, {'account_id': 8655, 'date': '2017-11-29 09:20:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 8788, 'date': '2017-11-29 10:36:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2

(1 comment)

+2 with a follow up nit'}, {'account_id': 8788, 'date': '2017-11-29 10:39:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Workflow

Oh wait, there are more projects involved, may be others want a say.'}, {'account_id': 20229, 'date': '2017-11-29 12:18:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

Dragonflow gates pass. No other issues from my end.'}, {'account_id': 23804, 'date': '2017-11-29 13:50:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I'm probably missing something but imagine neutron adds a gateway port to a router and we don't have a connection to ovsdb-server. It will happily work as there's no exceptions but we don't have the port yet so traffic through the gateway port won't work. With the exception, we would let caller decide what to do (in the example above, resyincing the router).

Also I think it's important to log that we're queuing the transaction and, when pulling it off, i'd log it too. Otherwise debugging things like bug#1731063 is hard."}, {'account_id': 5756, 'date': '2017-11-29 14:22:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Daniel: From the thread where you are calling commit(), it will queue the transaction then wait for the result. There will not be a result until we start up and process the transaction. I haven't tested it, but what should happen if you stop() -> commit() and never start() is that a TimeoutException would occur due to the Transaction.results.get(timeout) call--which is what would have happened before the patch that added the exception."}, {'account_id': 23804, 'date': '2017-11-29 14:29:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: -Code-Review

> Daniel: From the thread where you are calling commit(), it will
 > queue the transaction then wait for the result. There will not be a
 > result until we start up and process the transaction. I haven't
 > tested it, but what should happen if you stop() -> commit() and
 > never start() is that a TimeoutException would occur due to the
 > Transaction.results.get(timeout) call--which is what would have
 > happened before the patch that added the exception.

Got it, thanks! Then this patch fixes the race condition where we have probably reconnected and maybe we're going to raise an exception before is_connected is now True?"}, {'account_id': 9656, 'date': '2017-11-29 18:43:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2

(1 comment)'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-29 05:33:40.000000000', 'message': "Don't throw NotConnectedError in queue_txn

Before Ifc74a834ca1a7d914c7ca66d71b47694f9eef1e5, queueing a
transaction before we had connected to an ovsdb-server would
happily work. When the connection started, the run() method would
pull the queued transaction off the queue and process it. Adding
the exception added a race condition in existing code, so this
patch removes it.

Change-Id: I0b620b0040ef5f7cb99d2f27140f605e97f95512
Related-Bug: #1731063
"}]
commit_message:
Don't throw NotConnectedError in queue_txn

Before Ifc74a834ca1a7d914c7ca66d71b47694f9eef1e5, queueing a
transaction before we had connected to an ovsdb-server would
happily work. When the connection started, the run() method would
pull the queued transaction off the queue and process it. Adding
the exception added a race condition in existing code, so this
patch removes it.

Change-Id: I0b620b0040ef5f7cb99d2f27140f605e97f95512
Related-Bug: #1731063

commit_message:
Implement availability_zone_hints for networks and routers.

Adds an optional parameter to the create_network and
create_router-methods, for use with availability zone-scheduling of
network agents.

Change-Id: Ifb93a10415dc676f5cc56b5315f2dff24fc395b8

commit_message:
Repropose application credentials to queens

This proposal for the Queens release updates the spec to cover the
changes discussed at the Denver PTG[1]. It also fixes some
inconsistencies that were introduced in the final stages of the approval
process the last time, and also makes some minor wording corrections.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2017-September/122087.html

Change-Id: I7024208cc567f761a333001bf872af46fa0cf323

[{'account_id': 10969, 'date': '2017-11-15 18:33:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2017-11-15 19:37:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 12715, 'date': '2017-11-17 14:43:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2017-11-21 18:14:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

Question inline. Also can you link to an example log file?'}, {'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2017-11-21 19:47:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

We think we have stabilized the current logstash pipeline. Lets temporarily WIP this so we don't introduce any new load to the system then use the long US holiday weekend to see if we catch up on the job backlog.

Assuming that happens we can then look at merging changes like this next week and monitor how the system holds up."}, {'account_id': 10969, 'date': '2017-11-22 09:47:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

Sure, the file exmample:

http://logs.openstack.org/28/521728/1/check/legacy-tripleo-ci-centos-7-containers-multinode/2fb970b/logs/undercloud/var/log/extra/errors.txt.gz

I could be just empty if no errors:
http://logs.openstack.org/73/521273/1/check-tripleo/legacy-tripleo-ci-centos-7-ovb-1ctlr_1comp_1ceph-featureset024/c8a16c1/logs/overcloud-controller-0/var/log/extra/errors.txt.gz'}, {'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2017-11-22 21:39:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2017-11-29 17:24:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Workflow Code-Review+2

We now have a logstash and elasticsearch indexing pipeline that operates as expected. We are good to add new files at this point.'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2017-11-29 17:26:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 4162, 'date': '2017-11-29 18:12:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1 Code-Review+2'}]

commit_message:
Add errors file to be indexed by logstash

In tripleo we grep for errors in logs and put them in one file.
This patch is for indexing only errors file in logstash server.

Change-Id: I95021ca826c75d7750bc2e56243ecc638bc1a502

To play it safe, we should land this patch with our current defaults. This then exposes the ability for jobs that are failing on github.com to bump the values, test and report back to -infra.

I still think we might want to consider making the global changes in DIB, depending on the results, but this gets people started with making changes to unbound configuration.'}, {'account_id': 9061, 'date': '2017-11-27 21:19:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 9061, 'date': '2017-11-27 21:22:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 9061, 'date': '2017-11-27 21:48:59.000000000', 'content': 'Topic set to unbound-ttl'}, {'account_id': 4162, 'date': '2017-11-27 21:52:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 10969, 'date': '2017-11-28 15:54:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review-1

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-11-27 17:46:21.000000000', 'message': 'Improve configure-unbound role to support configuring TTLs

Given the volume and ephemeral nature of the nodes we are running jobs
on, we're interested in raising the minimum TTL to ensure we're not
needlessly querying domains all the time.

Some domains such as github.com or fedoraproject.org have low TTLs and
we suspect there is a correlation between their low TTLs and the fact
that we're seeing increased DNS lookup rates for these domains.

- Prefix variables with "unbound_" to avoid potential clashes between
  roles
- Add support for configuring cache-min-ttl and cache-max-ttl
- Improve integration tests

Change-Id: I6d9656cb07a694fc2f54f256a63af814c034ffb8

commit_message:
Add support for configuring TTLs in configure-unbound

Given the volume and ephemeral nature of the nodes we are running jobs
on, we're interested in raising the minimum TTL to ensure we're not
needlessly querying domains all the time.

Some domains such as github.com or fedoraproject.org have low TTLs and
we suspect there is a correlation between their low TTLs and the fact
that we're seeing increased DNS lookup rates for these domains.

Change-Id: I6d9656cb07a694fc2f54f256a63af814c034ffb8

commit_message:
General improvements to configure-unbound role

- Improve README
- Improve integration test coverage
- Prefix variable names with "unbound_" to avoid clashes between
  different roles
- Unbound will very likely be installed but don't assume it is.
  Add an assertion to fail early if it isn't.

Change-Id: Ib8ca105938afdc0ccb1f524df3cae916c845efb8

Fix doesn't hide them at all. As if packages doesn't have MAIN declared they won't be included anyway. If MAIN is defined files will be picked from their. But have None values for some packages and empty lists for others is not the right thing to do from my point of view."}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2017-11-17 15:51:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Why? "Not imported" and "properly imported" are completely different things. Before xstatic-angular-gettext provides MIAN, we explicitly have "angular-gettext.js" as a list (See commit e7ec65e55f50ba487c63a913ce2ca65bb0db42e0).
Does angular-gettext still work as expected even if it is not imported?

At least, I would like to see a reasonable reason we need to support older version which are not declared in requirements.txt.
